Con este crédito de S/. 1,300, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, implementará el tamaño de su negocio.
Sugey sueña con terminar su carrera y trabajar en su especialidad.
texts.en:
Señora Sugey is 29 years of age, belongs to the community bank "Fuente de Vida," and lives on Vargas Llosa 130 El Cortijo Street, district and province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Perú. She studied through the eighth course of systems engineering but got married and left her studies because she had two small children. Her business involves the renting of internet booths, typing, and doing work for institutes, schools, and universities. It is located in her house. With the first loan of 300 new soles what she repaid in 4 payments, she planned on going into the raising of chickens, but that did not happen. With this loan of 1,300 new soles ($425) which will be repaid in 6 payments, she will increase the size of her business. Sugey dreams of finishing her studies and working in her specialty.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the size of her business

loans.name: Miriam Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Miriam del Socorro S. S. tiene la edad de 47 años su estado civil es casada, esta señora tiene 4 hijos 1 varón de la edad de 25 años que labora en el hospital, otro varón de de la edad de 16 años que cursa recientemente el 2 año de secundaria, otro varón de 23 años que estudia y trabaja por cuenta propia y su hija mujer tiene la edad de 20 años y cursa el 1 año de su carrera, su compañero de vida labora como ingeniero civil, en sus deseos esta el darle a sus hijos una casa propia donde ellos puedan establecerse en un futuro y que esta represente las condiciones necesarias como propósito esta el mantener activo su negocio  a pesar de la difícil situación que pasa el país actualmente.


El tiempo que lleva en este negocio es de 20 años, la actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta de calzado, ella inicia este negocio por cuenta propia  por lo que ella siempre se mantuvo activa en los negocios y le gustaba trabajar de forma independiente y es así como forma su propio negocio, el financiamiento lo solicita para capital de trabajo que será utilizado para la compra de mas calzado ya que el producto lo transporta desde Managua y algunas veces de Chinandega y de esta forma puede obtener mas ingresos para su familia por lo que de esta manera hará la compra al por mayor después obtenido su producto realiza la entrega de sus productos a los diferentes clientes.
texts.en:
Miriam del Socorro S. S. is 47 years old. She is married and has four children: a son (25), who works in a hospital, another son (16) who has just entered the second year of secondary school, another son (23) who is studying and is also self-employed, and a daughter (20) who is in her first year of university. Miriam's common-law husband is a civil engineer.

She wants to give her children a home of their own where they can establish a family in the future. For that reason, she wants to keep her business running despite the difficult situation in Nicaragua right now.

She has been in business for 20 years, selling shoes. She has always been self-employed and likes the independence that this brings. She wants the loan for working capital to buy more shoes, since she ships the merchandise from Managua and occasionally from Chinandega. This will enable her to increase her household income by buying merchandise wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yoli Estela

texts.es:
La señora Yoli tiene 38 años de edad, pertenece al Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia y vive en la Urbanización Las Palmeras de San Andrés Manzana A lote 12, distrito y provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió secundaria completa y es madre soltera de una niña de 11 años.
Su negocio consiste en alquiler de habitaciones para personas solas o estudiantes, como es una mujer emprendedora también vende ropa en las Galerías Minchola como empleada de una tienda.
Con el primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas los utilizó en arreglar los lavaderos de ropa de la casa pensión.
Con este crédito de S/. 800 soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, colocará puertas que le faltan a 2 cuartos.
Yoli sueña con terminar de construir todos sus cuartos para poder tener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Ms. Yoli V. is 38 years old and lives in the Las Palmeras de San Andrés housing development, block A, lot 12, in the district and province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Perú. She is a member of the Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia (Santa Lucia Solidarity Group).

She finished high school and is a single mother with an 11-year-old daughter. Her business consists of renting out rooms for single people and students. Because she is such an enterprising woman, she also sells clothing at a store in Galerías Minchola.

With her first 300.00 PEN loan, which was repaid in 4 monthly installments, she fixed the washing machines in her guesthouse.

With this 800.00 PEN loan, which will also be repaid in 4 monthly installments, she will install doors in 2 rooms.

Yoli wishes to complete the construction of rooms in order to obtain more income.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Door installations in two rooms

loans.name: Zully Judith

texts.es:
La señora Zully tiene 28 años de edad, pertenece al Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia y vive en la calle Santa Catalina 425 Miramar Alto Moche, distrito de Moche, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió Secretariado Ejecutivo y actualmente sigue estudiando Computación.  Se casó a los 21 años y ahora tiene 2 hijos que son estudiantes.
Su negocio consiste en la confección de disfraces y ambientación de aulas de educación inicial. Lo realiza en su casa.
Con el primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas, compró su remalladora.
Con este crédito de S/. 700, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en telas, hilo, micro poroso, etc.
Zully sueña con tener una gran tienda de manualidades.
texts.en:
Ms. Zully D. is 28 years old and lives on Santa Catalina Street, 425 Miramar Alto Moche, in the Moche district of the Trujillo province, department of La Libertad, Perú. She is a member of the Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia (Santa Lucia Solidarity Group).

She took a secretarial course, and she is currently taking computer classes. She got married at age 21 and has 2 school age children.

Her business consists of making costumes and preschool classroom decorations, which she does from home.

With her first 300.00 PEN loan, which was repaid in 4 monthly installments, she purchased an overlock machine. She will invest this loan of 700.00 PEN, which will be repaid in 4 monthly installments, in purchasing fabric, thread, vinyl, etc. Zully dreams of having a big arts & crafts store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric, thread, vinyl, etc.

loans.name: Jessica Lynn

texts.es:
Esta emprendedora mujer de nombre Jessica Lynn P. Juárez tiene la edad de 30 años, su estado civil es soltera, ella tiene 1 hijo  varón de la edad de  12 años que cursa recientemente el primer año de secundaria, uno de sus propósitos es de proporcionar a su hijo un futuro mejor en lo que se refiere a los estudios, además en su deseo esta el mantener activo ambos negocios como seria el de su casa de habitación que es una pulpería y su otro negocio que es un kiosco que esta ubicado en la entrada de la universidad de león en el campus por lo que ella tiene administrar ambos negocios y por medio de esto realizara las respectivas mejoras en su vivienda para que en n futuro su hijo pueda tener un lugar que represente las condiciones necesarias tanto para ella como para su propio hijo.

El tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 5 años, la actividad económica a la que ella se dedica es venta de gaseosa y cerveza, sus inicios empiezan por intuición propia de experimentar  lo que seria la venta de estos productos fuera de su casa de habitación y de esta forma obtendría ingresos para su familia por lo que comenzó con pocos productos como: golosinas, galletas y gaseosa por lo que mas tarde recibe una propuesta positiva de parte de sus clientes y es así como forma su negocio el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que es necesario la inversión de mas productos por lo que la compañía de la coca-cola y otras tienen que abastecerla para que la Joven Jessica pueda ofrecer variedad de productos a sus clientes por lo que agradece trabajar con fundación león 2000 y las organizaciones amigas para que ella realice sus propósitos.
texts.en:
This enterprising woman is Jessica Lynn P. Juárez; she is 30 year old, single, and has one child, a 12 year old boy who is in his first year of high school. One of her goals is to give her child a better future with respect to his education. Another of her goals is to keep both of her businesses: a grocery store she runs from her home and a kiosk located at the entrance of the University of León. She manages both businesses and thanks to these she has made improvements to their housing so that in the future she will be able to provide a worthy home for herself as well as for her son. She has owned the business for 5 years, and works selling soft drinks and beer. She began by using her intuition and experimented with which products would best sell outside her home and generate income for her family, starting with a few products, such as candies, cookies, and soft drinks. Her customers gave her positive feedback and this is how she has decided that she must ask for working capital to invest in more products which she must source from companies such as Coca-Cola and others so that young Jessica can offer a variety of products to her clients. She appreciates working with Fundación León 2000 and its partner organizations so that she can carry out her plans.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sinak

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinak S. is 37 years old and raises pigs. She lives in Oambeul Commune, Banteay Meanchey Province, and is married with five children, all of whom are young and still live at home. Sinak's husband, Mr. Sengly Sok, is 38 years old and makes a living as a taxi driver; he leaves very early in the morning to pick up his first passengers, and earns approximately $10 each day.

Sinak and Sengly are applying for a $500 loan so they can pay the car tax for the taxi service, so that they will not be penalized by the policemen.

loans.use: To pay the car tax

loans.name: Mai Thi

texts.vi: Chị T. tham  gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005. Vòng vốn đầu tiên chị vay  3.000.000đ để đầu tư vào buôn bán thịt lợn. Hiện nay ngoài buôn bán thịt lợn gia đình chị còn đầu tư vốn để mua máy móc phục vụ cho nhu cầu khoan cắt bê tông của người dân địa phương.Với mức T. nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng, việc hoàn trả vốn của gia định chị T. rất T.ận lợi. Vì thế vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm máy móc phục vụ cho dịch vụ khoan cắt bê tông của gia đình
texts.en:
T. participates in TYM fund since 2005. Her first loan, 3.000.000 VND, was used to start a business selling pork. Today, beside selling pork, she and her family also invested their money in a concrete cutting machine to offer their service to cut concrete. Their income is 4.000.000 VND a month so they won't have trouble making the loan payment. This time she is requesting a loan of 9.000.000 VND to buy invest and buy more machinery to better serve their customers.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy machinery

loans.name: Chok

texts.en:
Mr. Chok T. is 42 years old and lives in Anlongsamnor Commune of Siem Reap Province. He has four children, all of whom attend school.

Chok makes a living as a fisherman; he therefore depends on the fish around Tunle Sap Lake and earns approximately 15,400 riel each day.

Chok's wife, Mrs. Hach Dong, 41, is a farmer specializing in rice crops. Chok is requesting a loan to purchase more rice seeds as well as more fishing tools, such as a net and trap.

Chok and Hach are pictured.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fishing tools

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Chị Trần Thị Trúc năm nay 36 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi và nấu rượu. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ chị đã vay vốn để đầu tư cho chồng mua máy khoan cắt bê tông  phục vụ nhu cầu của bà con trong xã. Hiện nay ngoài thu nhập từ chăn nuôi và nấu rượu gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu ổn định 2.000.000đ từ công việc khoan cắt bê tông của chồng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000 đ để đầu tư mua 2 tấn lúa dự trữ phụcvụ cho việc nấu rượu tăng thu nhập cho gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs Trần Thị Trúc is 36 years old. She participates in TYM fund since 2005. Before joining TYM fund she and her family's income came from raising livestock and brewing rice wine. With the loan from TYM, she bought a concrete cutting machine for her husband so he could offer his service to cut concrete to people in the region. Thanks to this loan, today her family has a third source of income of 2.000.000 VND a month from the concrete cutting service ran by her husband. This round of loan, Mrs Trúc is requesting 9.000.000 VND to buy stock up on rice for her rice wine brewing business thus to increase her family's income in the long run.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: stock up on rice for rice wine brewing

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị  Nguyễn Thị Đông năm nay 38 tuổi, gia đình chị hiện có 2 con trong đó có 1 con đã trưởng thành. Năm 2004 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào cửa hàng tạp hoá của gia đình. Hiện tại chị kinh doanh cửa hàng tạp hoá còn chồng chị làm thầu thợ xây. Hàng tháng thu nhập bình quân  của gia đình chị đạt 140.000đ/ ngày
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm các mặt hàng phục vụ ngaỳ càng tốt hơn nhu cầu của bà con địa phương.
texts.en:
Mrs Nguyễn Thị Đông is 38 years old. She has 2 children, one of which is grown up. In 2004 she joined TYM fund to get capital to open a grocery store. She runs the store while her husband works as a construction worker. Her family's income is 140.000 VND a day. This round of loan she is requesting 9.000.000 VND to buy more products for her store so she would be able to satisfy her customer's needs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy more products for her grocery store

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Vân tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2004. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi và buôn bò. Vốn là gia đình đã có rất nhiều kinh nghiệm trong việc buôn bò nên  công việc buôn bán của gia đình chị đang ngày càng phát triển. Hiện tại công việc này đem lại cho gia đình chị nguồn thu nhập ổn định 150.000đ/ ngày, ngoài ra hàng năm gia đình chị còn có nguồn thu khoảng 10.000.000đ từ chăn nuôi lợn, gà.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc buôn bò
texts.en:
Mrs Vân participates in TYM fund since 2004. Today the main source of income for her family comes from raising livestock and selling beef. Since her family has a lot of experience in this field, this business is flourishing. It is bringing in 150.000 VND a day for her family. They also raise poultry and pigs which brings in 10.000.000 VND a year. This round of loan she is requesting 9.000.000 VND to continue investing in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest in livestock business

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi: Chị  Bùi Thị Cảnh năm nay 50 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2004 .Hiện tại gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi, làm thúng cho thu nhập khoảng 1.500.000đ/ tháng. Ngoài thời gian chăn nuôi làm thúng bán  tại nhà chị Cảnh còn tranh thủ thời gian đi bắt ốc bán cho thu nhập 1.000.000đ/ tháng. Với nguồn thu nhập này ngoài việc hoàn trả vốn theo quy định gia đình chị còn tiết kiệm và đầu tư thêm vào chăn nuôi tăng thu nhập cho gia đình. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang có kế hoạch đầu tư vào dịch vụ khoan cắt bê tông nên chị xin vay 6.000.000đ để mua máy móc.
texts.en:
Mrs Bùi Thị Cảnh is 50 years old. She became a TYM fund member in 2004. Today she and her family raise animal and make bamboo baskets for a living. On top of that she picks/sells snails to increase her earning, this bring in an extra 1.000.000 VND a month. After making her payment toward the loan she is able to put away some savings and invest some in her animal raising business. She and her family have a new business plan: offer a service to cut concrete. They need a loan of 6.000.000 VND to buy a concrete cutting machine.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy concrete cutting machine

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phạm Thị Miên 57 tuổi, là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2004. Với số vốn 1.500.000đ vay ở vòng vốn đầu tiên chị đã sử dụng để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Sau 3 tháng dự án cho thu nhập 1.000.000đ. Hiện tại không chỉ chăn nuôi gia đình chị còn có thêm nghề đan thúng và thu nhập từ lương hưu của chồng và cửa hàng sửa chữa đồ điện của con. Tổng thu nhập hàng tháng của gia đình chị đạt 3.000.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ một phần chị sử dụng để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, phần còn lại chị sử dụng để đầu tư thêm vào cửa hàng sửa đồ điện.
texts.en:
Mrs Phạm Thị Miên is 57 years old, a TYM fund member since 2004. Her first loan was 1.500.000 VND which was used to raise livestock. After 3 months she made 1.000.000 VND. Today beside raising livestock, she and her family also make and sell bamboo baskets. Her husband receives a pension and their son runs a shop repairing electric goods. Their family income reaches 3.000.000 VND a month. This time she is requesting a loan of 9.000.000 VND which will be invested in her livestock raising business and her son's repair shop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock and invest in repair shop

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Hằng  năm nay 41 tuổi, gia đình chị có hai con trong đó có 1 con đang tuổi đến trường. Hiện nay chi đang làm công việc chăn nuôi lợn gà tại gia đình. chồng chị đi làm thuê còn con chị đi khoan cắt bê tông. Hàng  tháng tổng thu nhập của gia đình  chị đạt  4.000.000đ/ tháng.
Với nguồn thu nhập này việc hoàn trả vốn của gia đình  chị rất thuận lợi, gia đình chị cũng có nhiều điều kiện để cải thiện cuộc sống và đầu tư cho các con đi học.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua máy móc khoan cắt bê tông và đầu tư vào chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H. is 41 years old. She has two children, one of whom is of school age. Currently, her family raises pigs and chicken for a living. Her husband works has a hired hand, and her son works as a concrete cutter. Her family's income totals at 4,000,000 VND per month. At this income level, she is able to repay her loan comfortably. Her family also has the means to improve her living standard and the opportunity to send her children to school. She would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND to invest in machinery for cutting and drilling concrete and to invest in livestock raising.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Thi Van

texts.vi:
Chị Phạm Thị Vân năm nay 55 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2004. Hiện tại hàng ngày  chị Vân còn đi làm đá thuê cho thu nhập 35.000đ/ ngày, Chồng chị ở nhà  đan thúng cho thu nhập 1.000.000đ/ tháng. Ngoài ra hàng năm gia đình chị còn có thêm thu nhập từ chăn nuôi khoảng 5.000.000đ. Với mức thu nhập này hiện nay cuộc sống của gia đình chị Vân đang ngày càng được cải thiện
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 6.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thức ăn phục vuụcho việc chăn nuôi của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. P. Thi Van is 55 years old. She has been a member of TYM fund since 2004. Currently, she works as an ice maker for 35,000 VND per day. Her husband works has a basket weaver for an income of 1,000,000 VND per month. Livestock raising gives her family an additional income of 5,000,000 VND. At this level of income, Mrs. Nguyen's family's living standard is improved day by day. She wishes to borrow 6,000,000 VND to invest in her family's livestock raising business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phạm Thị Nụ là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương  từ năm 2004. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị Nụ chủ yếu dựa vào lương lái xe của chồng. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương chị đã vay vốn để đầu tư vào buôn bán phân đạm. Hiện tại công việc buôn bán của gia đình chị đang ngày càng hiệu quả hơn. Với mức thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng từ buôn bán và lương của chồng hiện nay kinh tế gia đình chị Nụ đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển. 
Với mức vốn 9.000.000đ xin vay  trong vòng vốn tới chị Nụ dự định sẽ sử dụng để đầu tư mua 2 tấn phân bón phục vụ cho nhu cầu của bà con trong vụ mùa tới
texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi N. has been a member of TYM Fund since 2004. Before joining the fund, her family depended mainly on the salary of her husband, who is a driver. After joining TYM Fund, she has borrowed funds to invest in selling fertilizer. Her family business is now growing. Her income from her business grosses at 5,000,000 VND per month, and, combined with her husband's salary, her family's income is steadily growing. Mrs. Pham wishes to borrow 9,000,000 VND in order to buy two tons of fertilizer to meet the needs of her customers for the incoming growing season.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch H., 44, is vegetable seller who lives in Svay Art Commune of Pursat Province. She buys vegetables from farmers and resells tH. in her home village and at market. Her husband, Mr. Bu Veng, 48, earns a living driving a motorcycle taxi and working for the train station. Together they have six children; one is married and five are in school.

Touch is applying for a loan to purchase a cow and decorate her house.

loans.use: To purchase a cow and decorate

loans.name: Ni Kadek Murtini

texts.id: Ni Kadek Murtini berasal dari desa kaliakah . Ni Kadek Murtini berumur 32 tahun dan suaminya bekerja sebagai petani. Ni Kadek Murtini memiliki semangat hidup sangat tinggi. Ni Kadek Murtini memiliki 2 orang anak, anaknya yang Pertama bernama Ni Putu Sri Muradiana Umur 4 tahun dan yang kedua bernama I Kade Agus Adi Angga umur 2 tahun.Kadek Murtini dari dulu sangat berkeinginan memelihara babi, karena tidak memiliki dana rencananya gagal. Saat ini harapannya kembali muncul karena ada kesempatan untuk berusaha, lewat program Dinari yang menyalurkan dana untuk program ternak dengan jangka waktu 6 bulan. Dan pembayarannya pada akhir periode pinjaman,dan akan menerima dana ini secepatnya.Modal yang didapat nantinya akan dipergunakan untuk membeli 4 ekor babi penggemukan. Harapan Kadek Murtini supaya dana ini secepatnya bisa dicairkan.
texts.en:
Ni Kadek Murtini is from Kaliakah village. She is 32 years old and her husband is a farmer. They both have 2 children, Ni Putu Sri Muradiana (4 yo) and I Kade Agus Adi Angga (2 yo).

Ni Kadek always wants to enter the business of raising pig, however due to the lack of funding she has been postponed that plan.

She has a new hope now as she will be participate in a 6 month loan program from DINARI. She is planning to use the loan money to buy 4 piglets to be raised.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy piglets and pig foods

loans.name: Khursheedan Taqadus Hussain Group

texts.en:
Khursheedan baji is a wife of T. H.. T. is a delivery man; he delivers items from one place to another. Khursheedan baji is a mother of three children - two sons and one daughter. Her elder son earns daily wages as a laborer. Her younger son works in a factory. Her daughter is 15 years old. She stays at home and helps with household work.

Khursheedan baji earns money with her embroidery work and stitching clothing. She also teaches her daughter this art so that one day she can make dresses without her mother's help.

Khursheedan baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to replace her old donkey with a new donkey and cart for her husband.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading goods. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Azra parveen baji wants a loan to buy edible items like chips and biscuits wholesale to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a donkey cart

loans.name: Ni Kadek Widiantari

texts.id: Setelah menikah dengan I Komang Nenten suaminya  Ni Kadek Widiantari dari dulu memelihara 1 induk babi. Dengan hasil yang diperoleh dari penjualan anak babi Widiantari bisa membantu kebutuhan keluarganya.Sekarang induk babinya memiliki 9 ekor anak dan rencananya akan dipelihara. Karena kekurangan modal akhirnya Widiantari mengajukan pinjaman ke Dinari sebesar Rp.5.000.000,- dengan jangka waktu pinjaman 6 bulan dan pembayarannya pada akhir periode pinjaman. Dana ini belum diterimanya dan akan diterimanya.Kandang sudah disiapkan walaupun sederhana hanya memakai bambu dan lantainya semen.Widiantari sudah mulai  mempersiapkan modal untuk anak satu –satunya Putu Agus yang sebentar lagi akan lulus dari SMU dan akan meneruskan ke Universitas. Harapan Widiantari beserta suaminya biar Dinari bisa secepatnya mencairkan dana yang dipinjamnya dan akan dipergunakan untuk memperbesar usahanya.
texts.en:
Ni Kadek Widiantari is a wife of I Komang Nenten. She has been raising a breeding pig since she got married to her husband. Now the breeding pig already has 9 piglets. She plans to raise them and sells them when they are grown up. However due to the lack of funding, she is applying for a loan from Dinari. The loan will be a 6 month loan program where she can repay at the end of the loan period.

She already prepared a simple hut for the piglets. She is hoping to use the proceed from the pig farming to finance her only son, Putu Agus, to go to university.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to finance the pig raising activities (Anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Komang Suwiti

texts.id: Komang Suwiti adalah seorang ibu rumah tangga yang setiap hari sibuk mengurus rumah tangganya .Suaminya  Ketut Doles seorang buruh tani didesanya. Suwiti memiliki 2 orang anaknya yang pertama bernama Mahartini umur 8 tahun baru SD, dan yang kedua Saka baru berumur 4 tahun. Suwiti mengajukan dana ke Dinari untuk membeli 2 induk babi dan sisanya untuk membuat kandang. Suwiti mengajukan pinjaman Rp.5.000.000,- dengan jangka waktu 6 bulan dan pembayaran  pada akhir periode pinjaman. Suwiti sangat mengharapkan agar dana yang sudah diajukan bisa secepatnya direalisasikan.
texts.en:
Komang Suwiti is a homemaker who is busy taking care of the home everyday. Her husband Ketut Doles a farm laborer in the village. Suwiti has 2 children, the first Mahartini age 8 in school (SD), and the second Saka just 4 years old. Suwiti requested for funding from Dinari to purchase 2 pigs and the balance to build pigpen. Suwiti requested Rp. 5.000.000,- (about USD450) for a period of 6 months with full repayment at the end of the 6 months. Suwiti hopes that this funding request will be realized soon.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase piglets and livestock supplies (Anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Rukhsana M.asif Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana baji is a wife of M. Ali. They reside in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the past 6 years.

Rukhsana baji is a very hardworking lady. She helped her husband in the building of their new house. She earned money by sewing clothes day and night. Rukhsana baji’s husband is a driver. He drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) and has been doing so for 5 years. Rukhsana baji is a mother of two sons. Her elder son is 6 years old and her younger son is 4 years old.

She is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw. The auto-rickshaw is creating many problems for the family and so must be repaired.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Zakia baji wants a loan to buy edible items such as chips and biscuits wholesale to resell retail. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy sugarcane to make into and sell as syrup. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy tools for her motor workshop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Majeedan Liaqat Ali Group

texts.en:
Majeedan baji is a wife of L. A.. They reside in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. They have been living in this city for the past 5 years. Majeedan baji is a mother of eight children - four boys and four girls. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in the neighborhood.

Majeedan baji and her husband have a dream to see their children earn a better place in life. Both of them are doing their best to see this happen. Majeedan baji makes embroidered dresses on order and L. A. has a business selling animals. They pool their profits to pay for their children’s education.

She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo. She plans to raise the buffalo and then resell it to earn more income.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading goods. Abida baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo to resell

loans.name: Rubina M.afzal Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is a wife of M.. They reside in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the past 8 years. She is the mother of two sons. Her elder son is 8 years old and her younger son is 6 years old.

Rubina baji started sewing clothes as a business 5 years ago. Then she started making her own, self-designed, clothes to sell in the cloth market. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the community. Everyone comes to him to buy groceries. Rubina baji and her husband have a good reputation in the community and in nearby towns. She is applying for a loan so she can buy groceries to help expand her husband’s grocery shop.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Razia baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Khalida baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Zareena baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for the grocery shop

loans.name: Ren

texts.en: Mrs. Ren M. is a 47-year-old villager in Si Sla village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer cultivates rice and breeds pigs. Her husband, Mr. Leng Ly, is cyclo driver. they have five children, two of whom are fisherM. while the three others attend the local school. Mrs. Ren M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her rice paddy more productive and to buy four piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and piglets

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Mrs. Nuon N. is a 52-year-old farmer in An Doung Samreth village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice and also breeds pigs.  Her husband, Mr. Mey Soka, is a teacher the local school. They have two children, one of whom is a construction worker while the other attends the local school.  Mrs. Nuon N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her rice paddy more productive and to buy five piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en: Mrs. Soeun K. is a 48-year-old farmer in An Doung Samreth village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who cultivates rice.  Her husband, Mr. Chea Chuon, is a duck breeder. Two of their are children are fishermen and the third is a construction worker.  Mrs. Soeun K.'s paddy is far from irrigation and the soil is infertile. In order to solve these problems, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy a pump and fertilizer to increase production.

loans.use: To buy a pump and fertilizer.

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mrs. Mon N. is a 46-year-old farmer in Roung village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.  Her husband, Mr. Toem Shear, is a cow breeder. One of their two children stays at home to do housework and the other attends the local school.  The soil in Mrs. Mon N.'s field is infertile and she has asked for a loan to purchase fertilizer and to hire laborers with two oxen to plow her field. She hopes thereby to increase her yield of rice.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers with oxen

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy stock and a scale

loans.name: Sabitri

texts.en:
Mrs. Sabitri M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. Thecho is one of the growing villages in Nepal. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. lives with her husband and daughter. Her husband, Mr. Dharma Lal M., works in Nepal Telecom, and her daughter is in primary school.

Mrs. M. is a wood dealer in the village of Thecho where she sells wood and timber to the carpenters. She started this business 5 years ago to help improve her family's standard of living. She is requesting a loan of Rs 20000.00 ($275) to buy a truck-load of timbers for her business. Mrs. Sabitri M. wants to earn more money to improve her family's quality of life.

loans.use: Buy timber to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his stock of flour, cooking oil and other food items

loans.name: Soem

texts.en: Mrs. Soem K. is a 27-year-old rice farmer in Roung village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Moung Phat, owns a rice mill. Two of their three children attend the local school while the youngest is too young to work or study.  Because her land is infertile, Mrs. Soem Khoun has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer make her crop more productive.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Voeun

texts.en: Mrs. Voeun S. was born in 1980 and she now lives in Trapeang Sdouk village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Ny Thon, is a construction worker. Their two children, 6 and 4 years old, are too young to work or study.  Mrs. Voeun S. cultivates rice in a field of infertile soil far from irrigation. In order to deal with these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a pump and fertilizer to increase her harvest.

loans.use: To buy a pump and fertilizer.

loans.name: Sekea

texts.en: Mr. Sekea K. is a 42-year-old villager in Tonle village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. He and his wife, Mrs. Nget Van, are farmers who cultivate rice for a living. They have four children, one of whom is a teacher in the local school where the others are students.  Mr. Sekea K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make his land more productive and to hire some laborers to harvest the increased yield of rice.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers to harvest rice.

loans.name: Nirmala

texts.en:
Mrs. Nirmala T. lives in Sainbu Bhaishepati, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband, son, and two daughters. Her son makes and sells candles in a local grocery store, and her daughters are in grade 12.
Both Mr. and Mrs. T. own a farm in Sainbu Bhaishepati where they grow seasonal vegetables. They sell their vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening. Due to a lack of modern technology they still depend on traditional farming, like compost fertilizers. Mrs. Nirmala T. is requesting a loan of Rs 10000.00 ($150) to buy various kinds of seeds and fertilizers for their farm.

loans.use: Buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Debaki

texts.en:
Mrs. Debaki K. is 31 years-old and lives with her husband and two children in Sainbu Bhaishepati. Her son is in grade 12, and her daughter is in grade 10.
Debaki and her husband, Mr. Manohar, opened their grocery store 2 years ago. They sell different types of groceries such as rice, maize, biscuits, and various snacks. Their children help in the shop, so all the members of the family contribute equally to the family's income. They depend solely upon the store's income to fulfill their needs. Mrs. K. is requesting a loan of Rs 10000.00 ($150) to buy various types of goods to sell in their shop.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chorn S. is a 54-year-old widow. She now lives in Trapeang Sdouk village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice and her only child works as a driver. Mrs. Chorn S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her land more productive and to purchase a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a cow.

loans.name: Noem

texts.en: Mrs. Noem C. was born in 1963 and she now lives in Tonle village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a widow and the mother of two children, one of whom is employed while the other attends the local school.  She has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to supplement her income from cultivating rice and thereby to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Mrs. Sor M. is a villager in Tonle village in Takeo Province, Cambodia.She is 38 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is one year old.   Mrs. Sor M. owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn for living. Her husband, Mr. Chhoeng Born, is a rice wine maker. Although she and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support their family well. Thus, Mrs. Sor M. decided to request for a loan to buy pig feed and two piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and two piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Kea

texts.en: Mrs. Kea K. is a 38-year-old farmer in Ang Thnout Koeut village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She cultivates rice to earn for living and her husband, Mr. Lach Sokum, is a construction worker. Three of their eight children are employed in a garment factory, four attend the local school, and the youngest  is too young to work or study. Even though she and her husband have different businesses, they still need to improve their living conditions. Thus, Mrs. Kea K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Hach

texts.en: Mrs. Hach L. is a villager in Ang Thnout Koeut village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is 35 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom attend the local school while the youngest is two years old. Mrs. Hach L. cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Dos Sovan, is a barber. Even though they have different businesses, they still do not have enough money to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Hach L. decided to request a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding cow business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a breeding cow.

loans.name: Theavy

texts.en: Mrs. Theavy O. is a 38-year-old widow who lives in Brasout Thmey village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. One of her three children is a make-up artist who specializes in  making up a bride and groom for their wedding ceremony. The other two children are enrolled in the local school. Since her daughter's business is going well, Mrs. Theavy O. is requesting a loan to buy more beauty supplies for her business. She hopes thereby to increase the family's income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy beauty supplies.

loans.name: Peter Musyoki

texts.en:
Peter Musyoki is a 38-year-old man who resides in Kayole, an informal settlement on the outskirts of Nairobi. Peter is married and has two children, ages 8 and 6, who are both in primary school. Apart form his family, Peter also takes care of his grandparent, father and stepmother.

Peter is in the tailoring business, having started Synthex Designs in 2000. He has previous experience working in the metalwork sector, and he also took a tailoring course at a local polytechnic. He began Synthex Designs with Ksh 5,500 that he received from a merry-go-round, and this enabled him to purchase cloth and materials and rent a kiosk. Peter now wants to increase his stock through a loan of Ksh 25,000, with which he wants to purchase suit materials, kitenges (cloth for local attire) and lining rolls. Peter would like to thank the Kiva lenders in advance for the loan.He will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy cloth and tailoring supplies

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha Y. is a 44-year-old widow in Thjea village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Her only child attends the local school. She sells brooms to earn a living. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to request a loan to buy more brooms. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more brooms for sale.

loans.name: Razia Abdul Sattar Group

texts.en:
Razia baji is 26 years old. She resides in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. She has been living in the city for the past 10 years. Razia baji’s husband is A. S.. He is a milk seller; he sells milk to different milk shops to earn a profit. He has 3 years of experience in milk selling. They have one son; he is one years old.

Razia baji has an interest in stitching and embroidery. For her business, she takes orders to stitch two suits on order per week. She charges $3 to $4 for embroidering and $1 to $2 for stitching. This work helps her husband and the family to pay the household expenses; inflation is increasing day by day and it’s difficult for one person to mange the expenses.

She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy milk for her husband’s milk selling business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store. Sarwar baji and Aziz Fatima baji each want a loan to buy peanuts to resell. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy the contract of a bicycle stand so that her husband can run the stand and charge fares to people who want to rent the bicycles.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more milk to resell

loans.name: Muth

texts.en: Mrs. Muth E. was born in 1976 and she now lives in Si Sla village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Hang Chhaum, uses a motorbike to transport water for sale. Even though they have different businesses, they still do not have much money to support their family of five young children. Thus, Mrs. Muth E. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: 40-Quãng Hưng Group

texts.vi:
Chị N. Thị Tú, năm nay chị 54 tuổi. Hiện nay chị đang sinh sống tại thôn ba xã Quãng Hưng TP Thanh Hoá. Trước đây 2 con của chị đi học, chồng chị lại không có việc làm, chỉ sống dựa vào hai sào ruộng. Bây giờ gia đình chị đã dần khá lên , chị đã mở được của hàng thú y tại nhà cho chồng chị. Các chu kỳ vay trước chị đã sử dụng vốn vay của Quỹ để mua gà con  và lợn giống  khi làm ăn có lãi nay chị tiếp tục vay mức vốn là 1.626.900 VND để tiếp tục phát triển chăn nuôi và đầu tư thêm vào cửa hàng dịch vụ thú y tại nhà                                     
Các thanh viên trong nhóm của chị cùng coa cùng mức vay gồm:
Chị N. Thị Minh vay vốn để mua rau muống, rau cải...để bán lại.
Chị N. Thị Chiêu vay vốn để chăn nuôi gà, vịt 
Chị B. Thị Thắm vay vốn để mở rộng cửa hàng may mặc gia công
Chị Phạm Thị Tình vay vốn để mua phân bón và rau giống
Chị Phạm Thị Huyền vay vốn để mua T.t lợn làm nem chua, một loại thực phẩm đặc sản của Thanh Hoá

loans.use: pigs, chicken, ducks, vegetable, pig meat...

loans.name: Trork

texts.en: Mr. Trork K. is a 60-year-old rice farmer in Ta Preas village in TaK. Province, Cambodia.  His wife, Mrs. Tet Mao, is a duck breeder. Their four children are all grown; three are farmers and the fourth works in a garment factory. Because the soil in his rice paddy is infertile soil Mr. Trork K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to hire laborers to work in the field.  He expects to thereby increase his harvest and his living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers.

loans.name: Shahnaz Noor Samand Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz baji is 39 years old. She is a citizen of a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the past 10 years. She is the mother of two sons. Her elder son completed his education through the 9th standard grade. Her younger son completed his education through the 8th standard grade.

Shahnaz baji’s husband has a business selling wheels for vehicles. He has been running a shop near their house for the past 4 years, but he has 20 years of experience in this line of work. Shahnaz baji stays at home and makes embroidered dresses. Her neighbors come to her so she can embroider their clothing. This work not only keeps her very busy, but it also provides income for the family. She charges $4 of each embroidered suit.

Shahnaz baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more vehicle wheels for her family's business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Manzooran baji wants a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable selling business. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy candies on wholesale to resell. Haleema baji and Munawar baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their milk selling business. Ghulam Fatima baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. Sarwar baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy vehicle wheels

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey O. is a 28-year-old farmer in Ang Thnout Koeut village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Muong Shat, repairs cars.  They have 3 young children. Mrs. Srey O.'s business is going well and she wants to expand it. Therefore, she decided to request a loan to buy more piglets and pig feed. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Luganda Kulya Group

texts.en:
Saydah is the Treasurer of the Luganda Kulya Group in Kasangali, a lovely village on the outskirts of Kampala. She’s been a member of this borrowing group for over six years; this is her 19th loan. Saydah is a 52-year old, hard-working single mother of three children. She also cares for her sibling’s four orphans.

Saydah raises broilers (chickens for eating) and layers (chickens for egg production) for wholesale delivery to local restaurants, grocery outlets and butchers. Her current stock is 200 head. In a typical week, she will deliver 12-15 crates of 30 eggs to her customers for 4,500 Ush per crate. She also sells several broilers each week for 4,000 Ush each. She uses broiler sales proceeds to buy more chicks and depends on the income from layers to support her family. Loan proceeds are used to purchase chicken feed in bulk quantities. Saydah prefers to buy quality chicken feed made with maize, fish, cotton and shells to improve the nutrition quality of her products and command a higher price at market.

All of Saydah’s children are in school. She wants to expand her stock to 500 chickens so she can send her children to better schools and provide them with better clothes.

loans.use: Purchase high quality chicken feed in bulk quantities.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao K. breeds pigs in Takom village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Nget Sarom, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Two of their four children work in a garment factory and the others attend the local school. Mrs. Mao K.'s business is going well and she wants to expand it. She has decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding and pig feed. She hopes to thereby increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Muniran Ali Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Muniran baji is a wife of A. A.. They live in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. Muniran baji has been living in this city for the past 10 years.

She is a very hardworking lady. She helps her husband to improve the financial condition of their family with her business. She knits clothes. Her husband works in a workshop.

They have two sons. Both of her sons help their father in repairing vehicles in the workshop.

Muniran baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy tools to start a motor workshop for her husband and her sons so they can have their own shop.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy chicken for her chicken selling business. Asia parveen baji wants a loan to buy tools for her bicycle repair business. Kaneez baji wants a loan to buy items such as chairs and tables for her barber saloon. Haleema baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy tools to start a motor workshop

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Khoeun K. is a 38-year-old mother of three in Pang Ror village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns one-hectare field for cultivating rice to earn her living. In her plantation, she faces a problem of infertile soil which adversely affects her crop. In order to solve this problem, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizers to make her field more productive. Her husband, Mr. Un Mean, is disabled. Of her three children, two are tailors while the other stays at home to handle housework.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to turn around her infertile field

loans.name: Prisca J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Prisca M. from Mbeya, married with no children. Prisca has been running a medical store business since 2001. Working for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week, she currently earns about $403 each month from her business.

She is requesting a loan of $650 in order to purchase additional stocks of medicine in bulk, and in the future, she plans to expand her business. Prisca thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of medicine in bulk.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Mr. I. Samuel is a 45-years-old, hard-working and determined man. He is married with 5 children. Samuel operates a retail hardware shop in the Buwenge-Budumbuli zone.

Samuel is using the loan to expand his business by purchasing more cement, paint, nails, iron sheets, padlocks and brushes for his shop.

The profit yields from the business are to enable Samuel start up another hardware shop in the nearby zone. He uses his income from the business to cater for the needs of his family members. He longs to father a sustainable, healthy and happy family.

loans.use: Purchasing more cement, paint, nails, iron sheets, padlocks and brushes for his shop.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Mrs. Sao K. lives in Pour Preas Sang village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Keo Soeng, work as hen breeders. Mrs. Sao K. is 52 years old and the mother of two, both of whom are working. Because their work place is too far from their house and they usually pay a premium for transportation, they want to buy a motorbike to commute to work. Thus, Mrs. Sao K. is seeking a loan to contribute to her fund to buy a motorbike for her children. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children

loans.name: Yan

texts.en: Mrs. Yan Y. is 30 years old and now lives in Prey Kla Thboung village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. On her farm, she has a problem currently that her field has infertile soil and a lot of pests which adversely affect her yields. In order to deal with these problems, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides and to hire laborers to work on the field. Her husband, Mr. Aum Soeun, is a fisherman. Mrs. Yan Y. is a mother of two young children aged four months old and five years old. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and to hire laborers

loans.name: Suzana A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Suzana M. from Mbeya, married with three children between the ages of 3 and 12 and also supporting one dependent who is an orphan. Suzana has been selling potatoes since 2001, working 13-16 hours per day, 4 days per week. She currently earns about $30 per month from her business.

She is now requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase more potatoes in bulk, and in the future plans to establish another business. Suzana thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more potatoes in bulk.

loans.name: Kosar Bashir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji is a wife of B. A.. They reside in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. She is 40 years old and a very active lady. Kosar baji is a mother of two children, one son and one daughter. Her son is a carpenter. Her daughter reads in the 5th standard grade.

Kosar baji and Mr. B. get up at five each morning to work in their field. They have land in an area named “Aziz-a-Abad” in the city of Pakpattan. They grow vegetables there. When the vegetables become ripe they harvest them and Mr. B. goes to the market to sell the vegetables.

Kosar baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer for her land so that they can grow more vegetabless and earn more profit.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Asia baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Allah Rakhi baji wants a loan to buy ingredients such as chick peas and rice for her food business. Taj baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes on wholesale to resell. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy a lath machine. Shahida baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies like wires and switch boards for her electric shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for agriculture

loans.name: Adalat

texts.en:
Adalat was born in 1972.  He lives in the Khachmaz region, in Garagurtlu village.  He is married and has 3 children.
You can see his brother in the picture.  Together, they have been in the cattle breeding business for 3 years.  Now they need a loan of 970 AZN to buy a cow and a calf.

loans.use: To buy a cow and a calf

loans.name: Gwali Mutala Group

texts.en:
Resty is a dedicated and happy mother and a hard-working productive farmer. She is 56 years old with ten children and three orphaned grandchildren. Four of her children attend university and two are still in primary school. Her grandchildren are also in primary school.

Kasanje is a beautiful rural farming community in the hills near Entebbe. Resty grows matoke, beans, maize and cassava and she raises goats, pigs and cows on her plot overlooking Lake Victoria. She also produces a local distilled brew made from millet called Malwa. Her husband farms coffee and vanilla, and operates a small retail shop in the nearby village.

Resty is using this loan to help pay wages for two workers that help her on the farm. She will also buy millet and wants to buy another goat. She has been a Pearl client since 2000. Small loans have helped her buy the plot she grows her crops on, which have provided the income needed to support her children through school. Without the loans, she would not be able to sustain or grown her business.

Well-dressed, engaging and conversational, Resty is a natural leader. She is Treasurer in the Gwali Mutala group, the women’s leader in the community parish and the Treasurer of a national agriculture association. She hopes to start construction on a new home one day and buy more plots of land for her children to sow. She is always looking for new ways to build her farm and would like more animals. School fees and caring for her orphaned grandchildren take most of her income, leaving little for savings.

loans.use: Pay wages for farm workers, buy millet for brew and another goat.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
N. B. is a 36-year-old father of 6. He runs a welding workshop in Kamuli, whereas his wife owns a drug shop in the same locality. Both partners are hardworking and determined to achieve financial prosperity.

N. is using the money to boost his business by purchasing more steel bars and tools for his workshop. From the profit, he hopes to finish up his residential home, purchase more land, and construct rental houses as another source of income that will enable him to see his children through school successfully.

loans.use: To purchase more steel bars/metals and tools for his workshop

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile E. is a 36 year old married mother, who lives in the village of Wome. There is no electricity in Wome. It is a small village located approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital.

Cecile makes and sells palm oil to provide for her family. This oil is an ingredient widely used in Togolese dishes. The process of making palm oil takes several days and requires considerable attention and skill. With this loan from Kiva, Cecile plans to buy a fresh supply of palm nuts to make palm oil to sell. With the profits she will earn, she will be able to pay for her childrens’ school fees and other expenses.

loans.use: Purchase supplies of palm nuts, with which to make palm oil to sell

loans.name: Fatuma L.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 50-year-old Fatuma K. from Mbeya, married with three children between the ages of 22 and 28. Fatuma has been running a used clothing business since 2006, working 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week, assisted by her husband. She currently earns about $200 per month from her business and is requesting a loan of $500 in order to purchase more used clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Fatuma thanks you for your support!

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost and the general appeal of anything western or modern. Some argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry, and there are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress. However, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia is a 44-year old woman with 3 children. She and her husband are working together in their photography business in the town of Santa Josefa, Agusan del Sur. They are renting a cramped government stall where the whole family lives and operates the business. They started their business by taking photographs during special occasions like weddings, graduation and birthday celebrations. Their business has been successful and they now have a photo studio of their own. Her major customers are the students and employees who want their photographs taken. They also accept laminating and picture framing services. The picture above shows Amelia and her husband working together.

She is applying for a loan of PHP 20,000 so that she can purchase an additional computer set, including printer, to meet the increasing demand for their services. In the near future, the couple hopes to expand their business to other towns (like Veruela, Trento and Bunawan). She also dreams of having a house and lot of their own and being able to afford a college education for their children.

Amelia has been a client of CEV for the past 4 years, and this loan is already her 9th. Through CEV, she and her husband were able to start up their photography business as well as have access to micro-insurance, training, and saving services.

loans.use: Purchasing an additional computer and printer

loans.name: Adjo Emefa

texts.en:
Adjo is the woman on the left in this photo, wearing the white dress. She is 29 years old and lives in Wome, a small village approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo.  Adjo is married with one child who will soon attend school.  

To pay for her child’s school fees and provide for her family, Adjo sells children’s clothes and t-shirts in Wome’s central market (where this photo was taken.)  

Adjo hopes to use this loan from Kiva to restock and vary her supply of clothing, so that she may stand out from competitors in the market and earn more money.  With the profits she will earn, she will be able to improve the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: Restock and vary her supply of clothing

loans.name: Gwali Mutala Group

texts.en:
If you met Eva on the street, you might mistake her for a diplomat. She is wise, professional, charming, and welcoming. She’s actually a farmer in the beautiful agricultural village of Kasanje, on the hills overlooking Lake Victoria. She raises goats, pigs, and hens and grows ginger. She’s also the Payments Controller in the Gwali Mutala Group, responsible to collecting and accounting for member loan repayments.

Eva is a 53-year-old single mother of 6 children, aged 19 to 33, and the foster parent of 2 grandchildren. This is Eva’s 23rd loan. She depends upon loans to sustain her business, which provides the family’s only income. She will use the proceeds of this loan to pay labor wages and rent on a plot of land she rents for ginger cultivation.

She tries to save money when possible with the hope of building a more presentable home and buying her own plot. She also dreams of having her own commercial vehicle so she can deliver her produce to the markets in Entebbe and Kampala. She currently sells her products from her home and is unable to command the best price.

loans.use: To pay labor wages and rent a plot of land for ginger cultivation

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en: Tahira is a widow with two children who lives in Khachmaz, a small town in Azerbaijan. Three years ago she went into business for herself. She is applying for a loan of $1,200 to improve her business by buying additional items to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Issam

texts.en:
Issam is a 45-year-old man who lives with in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their four children. Issam has been working as a blacksmith for 25 years. He requested a loan of $1200 from Al Majmoua to buy an electric generator. 

Issam builds iron doors and windows for homes. He is known for the  good quality of his work and his low prices. His clients are his friends and others.
 
When he first started his business, he faced some difficulties because he inherited the business from his father who left him with debts. Therefore, Issam had to reimburse accumulated business debt from his father. In the beginning, if Issam choose to start this business, it was in order to improve his financial situation. His future view is to expand his business.

loans.use: Issam needs the loan to purchase an electric generator

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thy S. is a 61-year-old widow who lives in Anlongthnoat Commune in Pursat Province with her two children. Thy is a farmer who usually grows rice and vegetable crops such as water-lilies. One of Thy's children, Mrs. Tho S., also grows vegetables to resell.

Thy is applying for a loan to purchase a cow and help pay for her business operation and, she hopes, make her job easier.

(Thy's daughter is pictured as Thy was unavailable at the time.)

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Koffi

texts.en: Koffi K. is a 31 year old married father.  He lives in the village of Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital.  Wome is situated in a lush and beautiful area of Togo near the border with Ghana.  To provide for his family, Koffi operates a taxi-motorcycle service.  With his motorcycle, Koffi picks up passengers along the road and drops them off at their destination.  This service is always in demand in Wome. There is no electricity in this village and people must often travel further than walking distance to take care of business.  Koffi hopes to use this loan from Kiva to purchase a new motorcycle.  With the profits he will earn from his business, Koffi can continue to send his children to school and provide for his wife and family

loans.use: Purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah M. is a 36-year-old hard-working and ambitious mother of four. She operates a general retail shop in Kamuli taxi park while her husband is a produce buyer and supplier within the same district.

She is using the loan in financing her business by purchasing sacks of sugar, maize and wheat flour, cosmetics and soft drinks for her shop.

She has hopes and dreams of running a wholesale grocery shop in the area. With the profits from the business, she will send her children to good schools so as to provide them with quality education. Her desire is to be a mother of a happy, healthy and sustainable family.

loans.use: The purchase of sugar, maize, wheat flour, cosmetics and soft drinks for her shop.

loans.name: Bineta

texts.fr: Cette jeune entrepreneuse intervient dans le secteur des NTIC. Elle gére un cybercafé en plein centre ville. Les collégiens et hommes d'affaires constuent pour l'essentiel sa clientéle. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer ses activités
texts.en:
This young entrepreneur operates in the sector of new information and telecom technologies. She manages an internet café in the middle of town. Middle school students and businessmen constitute most of her customers. She is requesting this loan to bolster her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Internet cafe and high-tech

loans.name: Binta Yami

texts.fr: Binta Yami D., 24 ans, mariée, 02 enfants  en charge est membre du banc villageois de Dinguiraye depuis 2 ans et demi. Elle veut renforcer son commerce de marchandises diverses en approvisionnant sa boutique en riz, huile, thé, lait, sucre, cigarettes, etc.  Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Binta Yami D., age 24, is married and has two children in her care. She has been a member of the village loan group of Dinguiraye for two and a half years. She wants to bolster her business of diverse goods by supplying her shop with rice, oil, milk, sugar, cigarettes, etc. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods for her shop:  rice oil, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Komla

texts.en:
Komla A. is 29 years old, married with children. He lives in Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. Wome is situated in a lush and beautiful area of Togo near the border with Ghana, but it is somewhat isolated. 

Because of his town’s location, Komla operates a taxi-moto business. Many residents of Wome take taxi-motos to nearby villages and Komla’s services are always in demand. Komla picks up passengers along the road and drops them off at their destination. 

To better serve his clients, Komla hopes to use this loan from Kiva to buy a newer, more comfortable motorcycle.  With the profits he will earn from this improvement, Komla can better provide for his family and save money to send the children to school.

loans.use: To buy a new motocycle

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 43-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, in southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Issam has been a car painter for 30 years. He has requested a loan of $1200 from Al Majmoua to buy new tools for his work. 

Hassan is known for his fast and precise work, and also the good quality of execution. His customers are his friends, his family, his neighbors and others. 

When he first started his business, he had some difficulty establishing a good reputation for his work, but now that he is well known in his area, he doesn’t worry about his reputation. Hassan decided to start his business because he always wanted to work on his own, to have a private business and not depend on anyone. He did his best to make it work. Therefore, his future plans are to expand his business as a blacksmith and a painter. Painting for him is very important; it helps him to express himself and feel better.

loans.use: Hassan wants the loan to purchase new tools for his business

loans.name: Neun

texts.en:
Mr. Neun T., 44, is a local fisherman who always depends on fishing in Tunle Sap Lake, which has a lot of fish. His wife, Mrs. Seap Ly, 44, is a rice farmer and they live with their four children, two of whom are working as construction workers to help in reducing the family’s daily expenses.

Neun is applying for 500,000 riel ($125) to purchase more fishing tools, including nets, traps and cast nets. The loan will help to increase his income, to buy food and to pay his kids' school fees. They all live in Chroloung Commune, Kompong Tom Province. (Mr. Neun's wife is pictured, because Mr. Neun was not available that time).

loans.use: To purchase more fishing tools

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en: Vugar (whose brother is pictured here because Vugar was away when this photo was taken) is a single man who lives in a village known as Garachay in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. He was born in 1975. Vugar and his brother have been in the cattle-breeding business for the last five years, and have applied for a loan of $1,200 to buy a cow and a calf.

loans.use: to buy a cow and a calf

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 40 year-old-man who lives in Nabatieh, in southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. He has been a blacksmith for seven years. He has requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase an electric generator.

Hassan is known for the quality of his work. He installs iron doors and windows. His clients are his friends, neighbors, and others. 

While work, he faced some difficulties because he had an accident in which he broke his leg.  As a result, his work was slower, which made him unable to handle big projects. Despite his accident, he has always been motivated. In the future, he intends to buy a bigger generator and small machinery to improve his business.

loans.use: Hassan needs the loan to purchase an electric generator

loans.name: Kurbonhotun

texts.ru: Ниятбекова Курбонхотун Лалбековна 1976 года рождения, замужем, имеет 2 детей. Курбонхотун работает в Медицинское учреждение Министерство Внутренних Дел города Душанбе медсестрой. Она хочет улучшить социальное положение семьи. Планирует Курбонхотун сделать ремонт дома. Она хочет получить с помощью программы Кива займ в сумме 2800 сомони чтобы закупить необходимые принадлежности для начатия ремонта.
texts.en:
Kurbonhotun N. was born in 1976, is married and has two children. Kurbonhotun is a nurse in an Interior Ministry medical center in Dushanbe. She wants to improve her family's living standards, and she decided to do some repairs of their home. She would like to receive a loan of 2800 somoni through Kiva, in order to buy the materials necessary to begin repairs.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home Repairs

loans.name: Diame Actions Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Diamé Actions est spécialisé dans l'offre de services : traitement de texte, reliure,photocopies. Il participe activement à l'insertion et à l'initiation des jeunes aux NTIC.
Ils sollicitent ce prêt pour acheter des rames de papiers et des consommables informatiques. Ce qui leurs permettra d'augmenter leur bénéfice.
texts.en:
The group Diamé Actions is specialized in offering these services: word-processing, book-binding, and photocopying. The group actively participates in the integration and initiation of the young into computers and telecommunications technologies. The members of the group are requesting this loan to buy reams of paper and computer-related consumables. This will enable them to increase their profit.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Word-processing and photocopying

loans.name: Boun

texts.en:
Mrs. Boun D. is 28 years old and operates her business by collecting hair around her commune, and wholesales to hairdressers for a daily income. She is the mother of one young child. Her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Srey, 29, is a motorcycle taxi driver who provides his service to passengers around his commune and currently earns $2.64 a day.

Boun hopes to enlarge her investment and she is requesting a loan of $600 to buy more hair to store and resell. The borrowers live in Chroneang Commune, Kompong Tom Province. (Mrs. Boun's husband is pictured, because she was not available that time).

loans.use: To buy more hair to store and resale

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel B. is a 39-year-old male Ugandan. He is innovative and industrious. Samuel is married with three children, of whom two are in primary school, while the eldest is in high school. His wife Joy gives him a hand in running their retail grocery shop located in Iganga Town, Wagoina Road. Besides this, he also cultivates and sells coffee to traders in the neighbouring towns.

Samuel is using the loan to mainly purchase some bundles of wheat flour, cartons of soap and sanitary towels, some sacks of sugar and rice, and soft drinks to fill up his deep freezer. The success of his business in the past 5 years is attributed to his excellent customer courtesy.

Operating a wholesale grocery shop is what Samuel desires because he is in a strategic business area with numerous customers. The income from his business enables him to see his children through school and also cater for the basic needs of his family.

loans.use: To mainly purchase some bundles of wheat flour, cartons of soap and sanitary towels, some sacks of sugar and rice, and soft drinks

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N., a hardworking, honest, and self-motivated mother of 4, is 56 years old. Three of her children are government servants in the ministry of health, and the youngest is in her final year pursuing a bachelor's degree in law at a Ugandan university.

Being a qualified and enrolled nurse, she operates Bagatya drug shop along Tororo Road, opposite Iganga hospital. Christine added the loan onto her savings and is purchasing more medicine for her shop. Previously, she has been using her salary as a nurse to finance her business. It is the income from her 15 years of her drug shop business that has enabled her to see her 4 children through university.

With her business located opposite the main hospital in the district, Christine intends to inject the profits back into her business because she aspires to own a wholesale/retail pharmacy that will be legally licensed to sell a wide range of drugs in the same location, so as to attract the awesome number of clients from the hospital.
