Even though they have different businesses, they do not have much money to live on. Thus, Mrs. Heng H. is asking for a loan to buy pig food and six piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve her living condition with this loan.

loans.use: To buy pig food and six piglets for breeding

loans.name: Vu Thi Kieu

texts.en:
Mrs. L. is 30 years old and lives in the Nghe An Province, in Vietnam. She joined TYM in 2005. She has two children who go to school. Mrs. L. first successfully completed a loan with TYM to start her own family motor-bike repair shop, which is her family's main source of income. With a steady source of profit, Mrs. L.’s shop is able to provide her family with the stability it needs.

Mrs. L. would like to borrow $600 to buy tools and invest in her family’s motorbike repair shop.

loans.use: to buy tools and invest in her family motor-bike repair shop.

loans.name: Chhuk

texts.en: Chhuk S., 25, is married and lives with her three young children and husband in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She and her husband work together as workers breaking rock on the mountain. On average, both of them make about US$3 each day. Chhuk S. would like to take out a loan of US$300 to purchase dynamite to break the rock.

loans.use: To purchase dynamite to break the rock.

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. T. is 51 years old and lives in the Nghe An Province, in Vietnam. She has four children, all of them of adult age. She has been in TYM since 2004. Her income comes from tailoring and selling cloth. Since she joined TYM, she has always repaid her loans on time.

For the next loan cycle, Mrs. T. wants to borrow $1000 to buy more materials for her tailor shop.

loans.use: Purchase more material for her tailoring shop

loans.name: La-It

texts.en:
Mrs. La-it N., 27, lives in Prey Kla Thboung village in Takeo Province with her family. Her husband, Mr. Nen Rei, is a construction worker. Mrs. La-it N. is a mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school while the other two are too young to work or study.

She farms a plot of land to cultivate rice, but because her field is infertile soil her crop yield is poor. In order to deal this problem, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to improve her field to make her crop more productive.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to improve her field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 52 years old. She is divorced, and has 3 children. She lives in Nghi Trung commune, in Vietnam. She has been with TYM since 2004. Her main source of income is from raising pigs and chickens. With her income, her family life is growing more and more stable. Mrs. Thi wants to borrow $550 to buy more chickens, pigs and chickenfeed to expand her business.

loans.use: buy more chickens, pigs and chickenfeed for raising.

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarom P. is 34 years old, married, and the mother of four children, two of whom stay at home to do housework while the other two are too young to work or study. She and her family live in Prey Kla Thboung village in Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Choun Rath (on the left in the photo), owns loudspeakers which he hires to villagers to earn an income.

Mrs. Sarom P. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. She faces some problems in her plantation -- the soil is infertile and some pests are so bad that they affect her crop. In order to deal these problems, she wants to buy fertilizers and pesticides. She would use the rest of money to hire some laborers to work in the field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides to improve her field.

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Sor S., 48, is married and resides with her seven children and husband in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Working as a village doctor together with her husband, Khem Kuy, 56, typically makes US$3 each day. Her family is also supported by four of the children who work growing rice. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. Sor S. is asking for a loan of US$150 to purchase more medicines.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov Y. is 38 years old, married, and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study because they are five months and four years old. They live in Krang Roung village in Takeo Province.

Mrs. Pov Y. is a farmer and owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Long Savoeun (on the right of the photo), works as a palm juice collector to earn a living. With their income, they do not have much money to support their family. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoang Thi A. is 32 years old. She lives with her husband and 2 children in the Nghi Loc district, in Vietnam. She joined TYM in 2005. She currently runs a beauty salon. This business developed well and brought for her family a stable income.

Mrs. Thi is requesting a loA. of $950 to purchase more tools for her beauty salon.

loans.use: Purchase tools for beauty salon

loans.name: Ni Nengah Weli

texts.id: Ni Nengah Weli seorang ibu rumah tangga,yang kesehariannya bekerja hanya membantu suami di ladang, sedangkan sekarang penjualan hasil pertanian turun drastic karena musim kamarau dan harga pupuk yang mahal. Oleh sebab itu Ni Nengah Weli berusaha untuk mendukung pendapatan suami dengan menjalankan usaha beternak babi. Namun usaha ini dijalankan masih secara tradisional dengan cara mengikat babinya pada sebatang pohon, hal ini dilakukan karena Ni Nengah Weli tidak mempunyai modal untuk membuat kandang. Kemudian Ni Nengah Weli mengajukan pinjaman ke Yayasan Dinari, karena selain mendapatkan pinjaman modal, Dinari juga memberikan pelatihan yang berkaitan dengan pemeliharaan babi agar nantinya mendapatkan hasil yang bagus. Modal pinjaman ini akan dipergunakan untuk membuat kandang babi dan membeli  pakan ternak sampai nanti babi ini siap dijual. Dengan adanya usaha ini diharapkan  dapat meningkatkan perekonomian keluarga dan anak –anak mereka tetap bisa bersekolah. Sesuai dengan program Dinari bahwa pinjaman ini akan dilunasi setelah akhir periode pinjaman selama 6 bulan.
texts.en:
Ni Nengah Weli a homemaker helps her husband in the crop field everyday, but recently income from the sale of crops dropped drastically due to the dry season and the high price of fertilizer. Due to that Ni Nengah Weli make an effort to supplement her husband’s income by carrying out pig farming. However, this effort is still done in the traditional way where the pig is leased to a tree, the reason that this is done is because Ni Nengah Weli does not have the funds to build a pigpen. Thus Ni Nengah Weli submit loan request from Dinari Foundation, because beside receiving loan, Dinari also provides training relating to proper pig farming so that later generate good returns. This funding loan will be used to fund building the pigpen and purchase livestock supplies until the pigs are ready for sale. With this effort hopefully will improve the family’s financial condition and their children have a consistent education. In line with Dinari’s program this loan will be repaid at the end of 6 months.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build pigpen and purchase livestock supplies (Membuat kandang babi dan membeli pakan)

loans.name: Khut

texts.en:
Khut M., 47, is married and has three children. She lives in Prey Veng, Cambodia.
Since 2003, she and her husband have been running a wood sales business to earn a living, making on average US$3 per day. The couple is also supported by two of their children who work as garment factory workers. At present, Khut M. needs a loan of US$700 to be able to purchase a sawing machine for cutting trees for sale.

loans.use: Purchase of a sawing machine

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Mr. Noun N. is 28 years old, married, and the father of two children who are attending the local school. He and his family live in Krang Roung village in Takeo Province.

He farms to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Men Savuth (on the left of the photo), is a grocer and her selling place is far from their home. She has to pay too much money for transportation and wants to buy a motorbike to get to her work. Thus, Mr. Noun N. is asking for a loan to add her savings in order to buy a motorbike for transportation.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation to work.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en:
Mrs Tran Thi H. is 40 years and lives in Nghe An Province. She has 4 children, 1 of whom is  grown-up.  She has been in TYM for 3 years. The fist time she borrowed 1 million to invest in raising pigs. Now this business developed well and this is the main income for her family. With an income of about 2 million per month her family has more money to invest in the children’s education and improve their living.
Now she wants to borrow 10 million to buy more cows and chickens for raising.

loans.use: buy more cows and chickens for raising.

loans.name: Preung

texts.en: Preung V., 35, is married and has three children, all of whom are still students. The family lives in the Prey Veng province of Cambodia. Preung and her husband earn income running a cow dealership, typically making about US$5 per day. She currently needs a loan of US$500 to be able to purchase additional cows for re-sale. Preung is confident that the loan will allow her to increase the daily income and help her better support her family.

loans.use: Purchase of cows for re-sale

loans.name: Ni Ketut Suparmi

texts.id:
Tinggal di rumah yang sangat sederhana yang hanya berdinding bata  tidak membuat Ni Ketut Suparmi dan keluarganya patah semangat dalam menjalani kehidupan. Segala kesederhanaan itu justru membuatnya bersemangat dalam bekerja untuk bisa hidup lebih baik lagi yaitu dengan beternak babi. Hal ini dilakukannya mengingat situasi lingkungan yang mendukung yaitu semua masyarakat disekitarnya adalah orang Bali  Terbatasnya modal yang dimiliki mengharuskan Ni Ketut Suparmi untuk mengajukan pinjaman ke Yayasan Dinari. Karena selain mendapatkan pinjaman modal dari Dinari juga memberikan training bagaimana cara menjalankan usaha ini agar mendapatkan keuntungan sehingga ekonomi keluarga dapat lebih meningkat.
Pinjaman ini nantinya akan dipergunakan untuk membeli 2 ekor bibit babi yang  akan di gemukan,Kemudian sisanya akan dipergunakan untuk membeli pakan ternak sampai nanti  babi ini siap di jual. Sesuai dengan program yang ditawarkan oleh Dinari bahwa pinjaman akan dilunasi setelah akhir periode pinjaman.
texts.en:
Lining in a simple and basic house with concrete brick wall did not dishearten Ni Ketut Suparmi and family’s enthusiasm to work towards improving living standards by rearing pigs. This is carried out considering the support by the surrounding situation, predominantly Balinese in the surrounding community. Limited by funding, impel Ni Ketur Suparmi to request for loan from Dinari Foundation. Because besides getting loan Dinari also provides training on methods of carrying out the business so as to maximize income thus improving the family’s financial condition. This loan will later be used to purchase 2 piglets that will be fattened. The balance will be used to purchase livestock supplies until the pigs are ready for sale. In accordance to the program negotiated by Dinari the loan will be repaid at the end of the loan.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase piglets and livestock supplies (Anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.en: Mrs  Hoang Thi H. is 38 years old and lives in Nghe An Province. She has three children. Her main income comes from raising ducks, chickens and growing rice. She joined TYM in 2004, has always repaid her loans on time. Now she a loan to invest in her poultry business. She can increase her income by raising more ducks and chickens.

loans.use: To invest in her poultry business

loans.name: Khom

texts.en:
Mrs. Khom K. is a villager in Krang Roung village in Takeo Province. She is 58-year-old widow and the mother of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is a ticket checker.

She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land and cultivates rice to earn a living. Mrs. Khom K. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living condition with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs Nguyen Thi H. is 49 years old and lives in Nghe An Province. She has been in TYM for four years. She first took a loan to invest in a small trading business. Now her family has a restaurant in Nghi Loc district, which is the family's major income. She is requesting a loan to increase her food supply for the restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase more food for her restaurant

loans.name: Art

texts.en: Art K., 27, is married and lives with two young children and her husband in the Prey Veng province. Since 2005, she has been selling many kinds of vegetables to earn a living and is able to make one dollar each day. Her husband operates a motor-taxi, earning approximately US$2 per day. She is asking a loan of US$250 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run his business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Nhanh

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhanh K. is 39 years old. She is married and mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school and she lives with her family in Krang Roung village in Takeo Province.

She is a rice farmer. Her husband, Mr. Nhoei Houy (on the left of the photo), is a construction worker. Since his work place is far from their house, he pays much money on transportation. He wants to buy a motorbike to go to work. Thus, Mrs. Nhanh K. is asking for a loan to add her savings to buy a motorbike for transportation.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation to work.

loans.name: Ni Ketut Nilasih

texts.id:
Dalam situasi ekonomi seperti sekarang ini sangat sulit bagi Ni Ketut Nilasih untuk bisa menyekolahkan kedua anaknya yang kini sudah duduk di bangku SMU. Apalagi penghasilan suaminya sebagai petani tidak mencukupi untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga. Untuk bisa menambah penghasilan keluarga maka Ni Ketut Nilasih akan menjalankan usaha beternak babi. Rencananya Ni Ketut Nilasih akan membeli 2 ekor bibit babi. Karena kekurangan modal maka hal ini terus ditunda,sampai akhirnya Yayasan Dinari memberikan pinjaman modal untuk usaha Ketut Nilasih. Selain memberi pinjaman
Dinari juga memberikan pembinaan kepada Ketut Nilasih tentang bagaimana cara beternak babi yang benar serta cara memberi pakan yang baik agar usaha ini dapat memberi keuntungan yang bagus. Sehingga dapat mendukung ekonomi keluarga ,sehingga anak-anaknya tetap dapat bersekolah. Sesuai dengan program ini bahwa pinjaman akan dilunasi pada akhir periode pinjaman.
texts.en:
In the current economic situation it is very difficult for Ni Ketut Nilasih to provide for her two children’s education now at SMU. Especially when her husband’s income as a farmer is insufficient to cover the family’s expenses. To supplement the family’s income Ni Ketut Nilasih will rear pigs. Ni Ketut Nilasih’s plan is to purchase 2 piglets. Because of insufficient funding this project had been postponed until finally Dinari Foundation provided laon to Ketut Nilasih for the project. Besides giving loan, Dinari also provides foundation knowledge to Ketut Nilasih relating to correct methods of pig farming and method of providing good feed so that it will generate good income. This enables her to supplement the family’s financial condition, so that her children can continue their education. In accordance with the program the loan will be repaid at the end of the loan.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase piglets and livestock supplies (Anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Luh Rahayu Astuti

texts.id: Mempunyai suami seorang pegawai swasta belum tentu dapat menjamin kebutuhan keluarga terpenuhi. Apalagi sekarang kebutuhan pokok semua pada meningkat.Tiga orang anak yang kini duduk dibangku SMA dan SMP membutuhkan biaya sekolah yang cukup banyak,oleh sebab itu Ni Luh Rahayu Astuti kini berusaha untuk membantu pendapatan keluarga dengan menjalankan usaha beternak babi. Karena kekurangan modal maka Ni Luh Rahayu Astuti mengajukan pinjaman ke Yayasan Dinari, karena selain mendapatkan pinjaman modal dari Dinari juga memberikan pelatihan bagaimana cara beternak babi yang baik, cara memberi pakan juga mengatasi penyakit,agar usaha yang dilakukan nantinya bisa mendapatkan keuntungan, dan ekonomi keluarga tercukupi. Pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari nantinya akan dipergunakan untuk membeli 2 ekor bibit babi unggul dan sisinya akan dipergunakan untuk membeli pakan ternak sampai babi ini laku terjual. Sesuai dengan program Dinari bahwa pinjaman akan dilunasi pada akhir periode pinjaman.
texts.en:
Having a husband who is a private official is not assured that the family’s needs are fulfilled. Especially as of now the cost of all primary needs had increased. Three children current in school (SMA and SMP) requires payment of substantial school needs, due to that Ni Luh Rahayu Astuti now expend effort to supplement the family’s income by performing the task of pig rearing. Due to insufficient capital thus Ni Luh Rahayu Astuti requested loan from Dinari Foundation, because beside receiving loan from Dinari will also receive training in the best ways of rearing pigs, method of feed and care to avoid diseases thus resulting in generating good profit, improving the family’s financial condition. This loan from Dinari will be used to purchase 2 piglets of superior quality and the balance to purchase feed and supplies until the pigs are sold. In accordance with Dinari’s program the loan will be repaid at the end of the loan.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase piglets and livestock supplies (Anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sorn B. is 41 years old, married, and the father of three children who are attending the local school. He and his family live in Krang Roung village in Takeo Province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Khat Heang (on the left of the photo), is an ice cream seller.

Their family doesn't have enough income to improve their living conditions. Thus, Mr. Sorn B. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. He hopes to increase his income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Sou P. is 35 years old and lives in the Prey Veng province of Cambodia. She has three children, all of whom are still students. Sou and her husband earn income producing and selling large jars. They are able to make about US$5 per day. In an average month, the family spends US$50 on food, US$10 on utilities, and US$10 on the children’s education. Sou is now asking for a loan of US$500 to be able to purchase additional materials such as sand, cement, rock, and steel to make more jars for sale.

loans.use: Purchase of sand, cement, rock, and steel

loans.name: Koem

texts.en:
Mrs. Koem K. is 51 years old and married and lives in Prey Kla Thboung village in TaK. Province. She and her husband, Mr. Hun Kimchorn, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. They have four children who all work, three in a garment factory.

Because their house is so old, Mrs. Koem K. is asking for a loan to buy timbers to rebuild it.

loans.use: To buy timbers to rebuild her house.

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en:
Mr. Chanthorn S. is 43 years old and he lives in Ponley village in Takeo Province with his wife, Mrs. Mol Nam. They are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. They have five children, one of whom is a teacher in a state school while the other four are enrolled in the local school.

Because their income is low, it is hard to save and they want to increase income. Thus, Mr. Chanthorn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Ouy

texts.en: Ouy V., 25, is married and lives with her husband and child in the Prey Veng province of Cambodia. She and her husband earn income making and selling cakes. They are able to make around US$5 per day. The couple is also responsible for looking after their old parents. To make more money, Ouy V. is asking for a loan of US$600 to be able to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate as a motor-taxi.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorbike

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S. is 25 years old, married, and has a child. The family lives in the Prey Veng province of Cambodia. Since 2005, Kong and her husband have been earning income selling coconuts, making about US$3 per day. The couple is also responsible for looking after Kong's old mother. To make more money, Kong is currently asking for a loan of US$350 to be able to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate as a motor-taxi.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorbike

loans.name: Chok

texts.en:
Mr. Chok T. is 49 years old and lives with his wife and five-year-old child (shown in the picture) in Krang Roung village in Takeo Province. He is an ice cream seller. His wife, Mrs. T. Ny, is a farmer who owns a piece of land and cultivates rice to earn a living.

Because their income isn't sufficient to support the family and build a kitchen, Mr. Chok T. decided to ask for a loan to build a new kitchen.

loans.use: To build a new kitchen.

loans.name: Rajabmurod

texts.ru: амсуддинов Раджабмурод житель города Нурек. Не женат. Живет с родителями в очень большой семье. Уже пять лет он занимается бизнесом . Привозит товар из города ДУшанбе и реализует в розницу у себя на рынке. Бизнес приносит доход , как ему , так и населению , которое покупает  одежду у него по доступным ценам. Кроме того им не приходится выезжать в город Душанбе за покупками . Сейчас Раджабмурод планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы увеличить свой товарооборот. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Rajabmurod S. lives in the city of Nurek. He is not married, and lives with his parents in a very large family. He has been in business for five years, transporting goods from Dushanbe to sell at retail prices in his local market. The business is profitable for him as well as for residents who buy clothing from him at reasonable prices. They also don't need to travel to Dushanbe to go shopping. Now Rajabmurod wants to use a loan to increase the volume of sales. The loan will be repaid over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Sales Volume

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Mr. Chhorn H. is 52 years old and lives in Ponley village in Takeo Province with his wife, Mrs. Leang Phan. They are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. They have two children who are employed in a garment factory.

Mr. Chhorn H. would like to buy an electric cow because they do not have oxen to plow their field. They also would like to start a new business of plowing the fields of other villagers. This would allow them to increase their income and put money into savings.

loans.use: To buy an electric cow to plow his field.

loans.name: Net

texts.en:
Mr. Net E. is 35 years old, married, and the father of five children who are enrolled in the local school. He and his family live in Rokar village in Kandal Province.

He and his wife are grocers to earn a living. This business is going well and they want to expand it. Thus, Mr. Net E. is requesting a loan to buy more goods for inventory. He hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more goods for inventory.

loans.name: Jurahon

texts.ru: Муродов Джурахон житель города НУрек. Женат. В возрасте 41  года имеет семерых детей. Два года занимается торговлей. Имеет киоск на центральном рынке . Торгуетразличными промышленными товарами , а так же газетами. Хочет получить кредит для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот, завезти свежий товар с новым ассортиментом. Это поможет развивать бизнес , расширить торговую точку и привлечь новых клиентов . Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месцев.
texts.en:
Jurahon M. lives in the city of Nurek. He is married, and at 41 years old has seven children. He has been working in sales for two years. He has a kiosk at the central market where he sells various commercial goods in addition to newspapers. He wants to use a loan to buy the latest goods to expand his selection and increase sales. This will help the business develop, expand the kiosk, and attract new customers. He will repay the loan over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Sales

loans.name: Gulruhsor

texts.ru: Кодирова Гулрухсор. 21 год. Не замужем. Живет с родителями в городе Нурек. Два года занимается бизнесом. Торгует фруктами на центральном рынке. Скупает товар у дехкан и продает по розничной цене. У нее много клиентов , но для развития бизнеса хочет увеличить ассортимент товара, путем получения кредита. Это поможет увеличить объем продаж и прибыльность бизнеса . Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Gulruhsor Q. is 21 years old. She is not married, and lives with her parents in the city of Nurek. She has been in business for two years. She sells fruits in the central market. She buys from small farmers and sells at retail prices. She has lots of customers, but would like to use a loan to further develop the business by expanding the variety of goods she offers. This will help to increase the business's sales and profit. She will repay the loan over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Kosar M.aslam Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji is a wife of M. and resides in Pakpattan, Pakistan. Kosar baji is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son has a sweetmeat business. Her younger son is in kindergarten. Her elder daughter is in 5th standard and her younger daughter is in 3rd standard. Kosar baji’s husband has a fruits & vegetable selling business. He buys fruits & vegetables from a wholesale market and sells them on a cart in different areas. Kosar baji helps her son in the making of sweetmeat. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more fruits & vegetables to expand her husband’s business. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Khursheed baji requests a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Haleema baji requests a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Ameeran baji requests a loan to buy material (sugar and tea) for her tea stall. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy fruits & vegetable to resell

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally S. is a group leader of six who all live in Romon Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a hectare and cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Choem Thy, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support his family. Aside from this business, he is a pig breeder who raises two pigs. Since this business is going well and he wants to expand it, his wife, Mrs. Phally S., decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

Mrs. Phally S. is 35 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is a laborer while three others are attending the local school. The remaining two are too young to work or study because they are two and five years old.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product and are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor because they allow loan recipients to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Naseem Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji is a wife of N. A. and lives in Pakpattan, Pakistan. She owes a two-room, brick house and has been living in it for the past 10 years. She is the mother of six children: two sons and four daughters. Her elder son works as a delivery man delivering items to customers. Her younger son is in 3rd standard. Her daughters are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Naseem baji’s husband has a vegetable-selling business. He buys vegetables and wheat from the wholesaler and sells it to different shops. He has been in this business for the past 10 years. Naseem baji helps her husband in the packing of vegetables and wheat in sacks. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s business. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Razia parveen baji requests a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Abida baji requests a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable-selling business. Bilquis baji requests a loan to buy spices to pack in small bags and to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and wheat for reselling

loans.name: Mrs. Yom Vov Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank consists of sixteen people and is located in Peak Reang Village Kandal Province. Mrs. Yom V. has been selected by the members as the village bank president. She is a 52-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is a fisherman and the other is a soldier. She is a fish seller and can make a small income to support her family. Aside from this business, she is also a pig breeder. Since her pigs are growing bigger and bigger, she does not have enough money to purchase pig food. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy pig food.

Mrs. An Rotana who is a group guarantor is also presented in the picture with the group members. This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term (EOT) loans. Three members have EOT loans and are not required to pay any principal on their loans until the very end of the loan term. The rest have monthly payment loans. EOT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. They allow loan recipients to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase pig food.

loans.name: Bashiran M.yaqoob Group

texts.en:
Bashiran Baji is the wife of M. Yaqoob and lives in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 15 years. She is the mother of one son. Her son's name is Mithu and he is in kindergarten. Bashiran Baji’s husband has a spice selling business. He has been selling spices for the past 10 years. Bashiran Baji helps her husband in making of small packets of spices. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more spices to expand her husband’s spice selling business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Syeda Nazia Baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. Suraiya Yasmeen Baji wants a loan to buy another bicycle for her bicycle selling business. Tasneem Baji wants a loan to buy wheat to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more spices to resell

loans.name: Met's Group

texts.en: Mr. Met N. is the leader of the five members of a group loan in the Krang Ta Chan village in Takeo province, Cambodia. Mr. Met N. is 24 years old, and he breeds pigs. His business is going well, and he wants to expand it. He is requesting a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. His wife, Mrs. Soem La, has a plot of land in a rice field, and she cultivates and sells the rice.

loans.use: Buy more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Syeda Fayyaz Syed Mazhar Ali Shah Group

texts.en:
Syeda Fayyaz baji is 40 years old and lives Pakpattan, Pakistan. She owns a two-room, brick house. Her husband, S. M. A. S., is a homeopathic (treats illness with herbs) doctor. He has 4 years experience in this work. Fayyaz baji is a mother of six children: four daughters and two sons. Her sons are in kindergarten. All of her daughters are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Fayyaz baji’s husband has a good reputation in the community. Most of the people come to take medicine from him. Fayyaz baji helps her husband in the making of herbal medicines. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more herbs to make medicines. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Humaira baji requests a loan to buy vegetables to resell. Aqeela baji requests a loan to buy phones for her mobile phone shop. Sakina baji requests a loan to buy spices to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy herbs for herbal medicine recipes

loans.name: Syeda Raheela Syed Aftab Ahmad Shah Group

texts.en:
Syeda Raheela baji is a wife of S. A. A. S. and lives Pakpattan, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 35 years. Raheela baji is the mother of two sons. Her elder son has a vegetable-selling business. Her younger son is in 8th standard. Raheela baji’s husband also has a vegetable-selling business. He buys vegetables from wholesalers and sells them to different shops. Raheela baji helps him pack the vegetables for sale. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more vegetables for her husband. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Syeda Rashida baji requests a loan to buy materials (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business. Uzma baji requests a loan to buy spices to resell. Sakina baji requests a loan to buy vegetables to resell. Shaheen baji and Nawab baji each request a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy vegetables wholesale for reselling

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Khalida Parveen Zulfiqar Group

texts.en:
Khalida parveen baji is a wife of Mr. Z. and lives in Pakpattan, Pakistan. She owns a two-room, brick house and has been living in it for the past 10 years. She is the mother of eight children: four sons and four daughters. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Khalida baji’s husband works in a rice mill. Khalida baji herself has a sewing business. She has been sewing clothes for the past five years, and charges $2 per suit. She is applying for a loan to buy an electric sewing machine so that she will be able to sew more clothes and earn more profit. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Zahran baji requests a loan to buy fruits to resell. Khursheed baji requests a loan to buy vehicles wheels to resell. Ameena baji requests a loan to buy wood to resell. Khadija baji requests a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine improve her seamstress business

loans.name: Mutungo Samali Group

texts.en:
Juliet W. is the sole proprietor of Julie’s Big Bites, a catering service and maker of snack foods like cookies, doughnuts, muffins and crackers. She caters conferences, parties, seminars and traditional weddings and specializes in local traditional favorites like matoke, samosas and fish fingers. She sells her snack foods to retail food stores. She launched Julie’s Big Bite a little over a year ago, turning a hobby into her profession. Prior, Juliet was a community worker. Juliet uses her community ties to market her services.

Juliet is a single mother raising 2 children aged 10 and 12. Both her children attend the best boarding schools she can afford. She works hard and depends upon her income to keep both of her kids in school. She will use the loan proceeds to buy wholesale ingredients like sugar, flour and cooking oil. Juliet used to have to buy these ingredients from retail stores. Now her profits will rise and she can buy more ingredients to expand her operations. For example, she wants to introduce coated ground nuts (like peanut M&M’s). Loans are also a hedge against rising food costs - the global financial crisis has increased retail prices in Uganda, and buying in bulk will help her reduce her costs.

Her ambition is to grow into a national packaged goods brand and supply hotels and the largest grocery supermarkets. With her savings, Juliet is constructing a new home for her family. She hopes to see both her children become university graduates.

loans.use: Buying wholesale ingredients like sugar, flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mutungo Samali-Beatrice Group

texts.en:
Beatrice A. inherited a small plot of swamp land on the shores of Lake Victoria. Seemingly worthless, she found a way to turn it into an income-producing asset. She dredges the muddy clay soil and turns it into building bricks that she sells by the pallet to construction firms. Beatrice is perhaps the only woman in Uganda in this highly male-dominated profession. She employs village boys to help her with the hard labor of baking and piling the manufactured bricks.

Beatrice is 48 years old, married with 3 children aged 5-16. All her children are in school. She started her brick-making business a few years ago on a smaller scale to provide the income needed to pay school fees. This is her first loan. She will use the proceeds to buy firewood for the furnace, pay labor wages and purchase additional shovels and wheelbarrows. Beatrice can sell bricks for a bulk price of 80 to 100 Ush depending on the quantity. In a good week, she will sell 3,000 bricks and she feels her manufacturing capacity could be as high as 15,000 bricks per week. One of her business goals is to expand into this capacity. Her other goal is to buy a plot of land and built rental homes to provide further income so that she can save for university fees.

loans.use: Buying firewood for the furnace, pay labor wages and purchase additional shovels and wheelbarrows.

loans.name: Chetha

texts.en:
Mr. Chetha M. is 44 years old and a pig breeder, who took on this work a long time ago and has much experience in gaining income to sustain his family’s expenses. He also helps in his wife’s business to buy groceries from the local market to sell. His wife, Mrs. Nara Thoang, 40, is a grocery seller who has attracted many clients who buy from her business; most of them are neighbors and live near her house. The couple has two children, both of whom go to high school. They live in the Veal Commune in Pursat Province.

Chetha would like to request a loan of 1,500,000 riel to purchase more piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets

loans.name: Nkambo-Monica Group

texts.en:
Monica is a 32-year old widow and mother of a 12-year old daughter. To make ends meet after her husband died in Uganda’s civil war 11 years ago, Monica moved with her daughter to the village of Kitintale in Kampala and opened a hair salon with the little savings she had. She was previously an employee in a salon, where she learned her skills. She wins business by keeping a very clean shop and through her attentive customer service and hair care expertise.

This is Monica’s first loan with BRAC. She is using the loan to buy a refrigerator so she can sell cold drinks to her customers. She is also stocking up on braids, chemicals and other beauty supplies for the busy upcoming festive season. She charges on average 10,000 Ush to braid a customer’s hair and she services eight customers in a typical week.

Monica wants to introduce a barber chair to her salon so she can expand her clientele to include men. She dreams of building a house for her and her daughter on a small plot of land she inherited from her deceased mother. Monica supplements her income by growing cassava, beans and maize. Combined, she can afford to keep her daughter in school.

loans.use: Buying a refrigerator and also stocking up on braids, chemicals and other beauty supplies.

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en: Happiness struggled to open a shop with the assistance of LAPO Microfinance. Happiness sells second-hand shoes, bags, and clothing in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria. Happiness keeps her shop open from Monday to Saturday, and she has been in this business for the past 4 years. Happiness is 26 years old. She is married and has 3 children. Happiness hopes to stock her shop with more second-hand clothing, shoes, and bags. She is asking for a loan of N100, 000 ($850) to purchase more second-hand inventory for resale. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand clothing, shoes, and bags for resale

loans.name: Bukola

texts.en: Bukola is 32 years old. She is married and has three children. She is a committed LAPO MICROFINANCE client who has never defaulted on her LAPO loans. Bukola sells children’s clothes and has been in this business for the past five years. She is asking for a loan of  50,000 naira ($425) so that she can buy clothing in bulk. With this extra inventory, she'll be able to meet customer demand during the festive season. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase children's clothes for resale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther sells rice, garri (cassava flour), and other staples. She also sells frozen foods, such as chicken and turkey. She travels to Contonou to purchase the frozen foods she resells in Lagos. Esther is asking for a loan of 140,000 naira ($1200) to purchase more rice and garri for resale.

Esther is 45 years old. She is married and has seven children. Her eldest child is 27 years old, and her youngest is 13 years old.

Esther is a LAPO client. She expressed her profound gratitude to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva for their kind support.

loans.use: To purchase garri and rice for resale

loans.name: Nkambo-Specioza Group

texts.en:
Specioza N. is a single, 30-year old mother of four children, aged six to thirteen. She sells used clothing on the streets in the Kitintale village of Kampala early each morning to late in the evening. Three times a week she takes public transportation to the Owino market, Kampala’s busiest wholesale exchange, to buy bales of second-hand clothes.

This is Specioza’s first loan with BRAC. She will use the proceeds to purchase bales of bulk used clothing in larger quantities to lock in a lower cost and expand her inventory for the busy festive (Holiday) buying season. She makes less than 20,000 Ush a day.

Increasing her revenue and profit are important to Specioza, as she provides the family’s only income. School fees are 300,000 Ush per term. Including books and school supplies, school cost Specioza over 1,000,000 Ush per year. Paying school fees in addition to other living costs makes it difficult to feed her children two meals in a day when sales are down.

Specioza’s dream is to educate her children to the university level, earn enough to begin a savings account, and to open her own clothing boutique to relieve the physical burden of carrying a heavy bag all day.

loans.use: Purchase bales of bulk used clothing in larger quantities

loans.name: Ada

texts.en:
Ada I. is 47 years old, married and the mother of two children. She lives in the town of Okoko, in the state of Lagos, Nigeria. Her business is supplying notebooks, textbooks and uniforms to schools.

She is requesting a loan of N140,000 to purchase additional supplies of books and materials to make school uniforms. Ada is grateful to the LAPO Microfinance organization and to Kiva for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase supplies of notebooks, textbooks and school uniforms

loans.name: Mrs. Roatha Chhun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people in the Pou Roung Village Takeo Province in Cambodia have joined together for a village bank loan and they will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Roatha C. was selected as the village bank president. She is a grocer in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Nimal Thaong, is a construction worker. Although they have different businesses, they still cannot support the family well. In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. Roatha C. is requesting a loan to buy piglets to start a new business. Mrs. Roatha C. is 38 years old and the mother of three children, who all attend the local school.

loans.use: Buy piglets to start a new business

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a professional caterer of indoor and outdoor events. She bakes cakes of different kinds and shapes for her customers.

Helen is 36 years old. She's been in the catering business for the past 3 years.

Helen is asking for a loan amount of 100,000 naira ($850) to purchase more baking equipment and cooking supplies so that she can meet the growing demands of her numerous customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase catering supplies

loans.name: Broem's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Broem V. is the leader of four group members, who all live in the Samroung village in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. She is a grocer in the local market, and her business is doing well. So she is requesting a loan to buy more groceries to expand the inventory in her shop and thus expand her business. Her husband, Mr. Leng Chin, is a construction worker, who earns a small amount toward supporting the family. Mrs. Broem V. is 26 years old and the mother of a 3-year-old child.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to increase inventory and profits

loans.name: Christy Owari

texts.en: Thirty-three-year-old Christy is a fashion designer who also sells clothes and tailoring materials. Christy has two sewing machines. She is a LAPO client. She is married and has 3 children ranging in age from 7 years to 7 months. Christy lives in Ijaniki, Lagos state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for the past 2  years. Christy is asking for a loan of N120,000 ($1025) to purchase clothes and tailoring materials. She is happy because the festive season is fast approaching, and the demand for her tailoring skills will be high. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and tailoring supplies

loans.name: Yarikul

texts.ru: Ярикул Гулаев житель города Яван. ЖИвет вместе со своей большой семьей. Ему 35 лет , он женат и имеет пятерых детей. Занимается бизнесом в сфере животноводства. Уже пять лет работает на рынке "Фаровон". Скупает породистых бычков и через некоторое время после откормки продает по более выгодной цене. Сейчас планирует получить кредит сроком на 12 месяцев , для того, чтобы купить породистого бычка. Это увеличит его товарооборот и поможет ему развивать бизнес.
texts.en:
Yarikul G. lives in the city of Yavan. He lives with his large family. He is 35, married, and has five children. He works in animal husbandry. He has worked in the Farovon market for five years. He buys thoroughbred calves, fattens them, and sells them for a higher price. He wants to take out a loan for twelve months in order to buy a thoroughbred calf. It will increase his sales and help him develop his business.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buyin a calf

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en: Jumoke is a beautician; she sells weave-ons, hair extensions, and hair creams. She has been in this business for a long time. Jumoke has many loyal customers, in part because she has made her shop such an attractive, pleasant place to be. Jumoke is 40 years old. She is married and has 3 children. Jumoke is asking for a loan of N20,000 ($1025) to purchase more weave-ons and hair extensions that she can resell in her shop. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more weave-ons and hair extensions to sell in her beauty parlor

loans.name: Phanna's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phanna C. is the group leader of six members who all live in the Thmei village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who cultivates rice on a small piece of land. Her husband, Mr. Pich Rom, is a fisherman (pictured). He can gather only a small number of fish to support the family, because he does not have enough fishing tools.

So Mrs. Phanna C. requests a loan to buy fishing nets for her husband's fishing business. Mrs. Phanna C. is 43 years old and the mother of two children; one is working, and the other child attends the local school.

loans.use: Buy fishnets for fishing business

loans.name: Siphat

texts.en:
Mr. Siphat P. is 45 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sokra Koy, is 42 years old, and they live in Svayloung Commune, Pursat Province. They are both rice farmers who have been farming for 24 years in the area of their homeland. They care for five children, three of whom are students and two are still young and live at home.

Siphat is applying for a loan of 600,000 riel ($150) to purchase a cow to use for plowing his farmland. The loan will help him to increase his rice production to higher than previous years. (Mr. Siphat’s wife is pictured, because he was busy).

loans.use: To purchase a cow for plowing his farmland

loans.name: Muyibout

texts.en: Muyibout is 42 years old and married. She has 5 children. Muyibout sells medicinal herbs and native pots used to steep herbal teas. Muyibout’s family is very grateful to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva for their financial support. Muyibout is asking for a loan of N140,000 ($1200) to increase her inventory of traditional herbal pots and herbs.

loans.use: To purchase medicinal herbs and herbal pots.

loans.name: Nat's Group

texts.en: Mr. Nat M. is the leader of a four-member group; they all live in the Kampong Prasat village, in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. He is a fisherman, but he can only catch a small amount of fish to support the family. To catch more fish, Mr. Nat M. requests a loan to buy more fishing nets for his business. His wife, Mrs. Loch Sarim, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Mr. Nat M. is 32 years old, and has four children; two attend the local school, and two are too young to go to school.

loans.use: Buy fishing nets to catch more fish to sell

loans.name: Mr. Sophat Sam Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mr. Sophat S. was selected to be the village bank president of the group loan that includes eight people living in the Kampong Beong village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Mr. Sophat S. is fisherman, but he can gather only a small quantity of fish, because he does not have enough fishing equipment to catch more fish. He requests a loan to buy more fishing nets for his business; he hopes to catch more fish to support the household. His wife, Mrs. Un Sophea, owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Mr. Sophat S. is 26 years old and the father of two very young children.

loans.use: Buy more fishing nets to catch more fish

loans.name: Safarali

texts.ru: Холматов Сафарали проживает в городе Яван. Работает на рынке . Занимается животноводством уже три года. Женат и имеет троих детей. Хочет получить кредит для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот , путем покупки мелкорогатого скота.ПОгасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Safarali H. lives in the city of Yavan, where he works at the market. He has been raising animals for the past three years. He is married and has three children. He wants to use a loan to increase sales by buying some small livestock. The loan will be repaid over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheep and goats

loans.name: Mrs. Buo Bou Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Bou B. was selected as the village bank president by the group of fifteen people living in Da Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Mrs. Bou B. is a vegetable farmer, who grows beans to sell. Her husband, Mr. Soth Sim, is a fisherman. Although she and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot earn enough to support the family well. So Mrs. Bou B. requests a loan to buy a pig to start a pig-breeding business. She is 25 years old and has a one-year-old child. (Mrs. Morn Sokhum's husband, who is requesting a loan, is also in the picture.)

loans.use: Buy a pig to start breeding business

loans.name: Rajabali

texts.ru: Ташпулотов Раджабали житель города Яван. Возраст 56 лет, женат и имеет четверых детей. Обеспечивает семью путем разведения крупно рогатого скота. Имеет хозяйство , где имеет нескольких бычков. Узнав, про возможность получить кредит обратился к нам за помощью. Получив кредит он планирует купить еще одного бычка. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Rajabali T. lives in Yavan. He is 56 years old, is married and has 4 children. Rajabali supports his family by raising large livestock. He has a plot where he has several calves. When he found out about the opportunity to take out a loan he turned to us for help. After taking out a loan he plans to purchase one more calf. Rajabali plans to pay back the loan over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a calf

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo is a small-scale businesswoman. She believes that “the sun shall soon shine,” that is, her life and her business will soon have a new turn. This is because she now has new capital from LAPO Microfinance and Kiva, and she is very happy. 

Taiwo is 32 years of age and she has 3 children. Taiwo sell jewelry door-to-door, from street to street, and from community to community. Taiwo’s business is very small, but she is hard-working and she wants to increase the prosperity of her business and that of her family. 

Taiwo needs a loan of N50, 000 ($425 USD) to enable her buy more jewelry and to open a shop for her business. She is grateful to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more jewelry and rent a shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: A Septic Tank, Beds, Mattresses, Bed Linens, and Renovations

loans.name: Safargul

texts.ru: Розикова Сафаргул жительница города Яван. Возраст 27 лет,замужем и имеет двоих детей. Имеет магазинг рядом с домом, где продает продукты питания. Ее бизнес помогает населению делать покупки не выезжая далеко на рынок. Для того, чтобы увеличить бизнес , а так же удовлетворить спрос населения , она планирует получить кредит и увеличить ассортимент товара. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Safargul R. lives in the city of Yavan. She is 27 years old, married, and has two children. She has a store near her home where she sells foods. Her business helps give residents local access to goods so they don't have to travel far to the market. To increase business and meet customer demand, she decided to apply for a loan and expand her inventory. The loan will be repaid over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Sales

loans.name: Nurali

texts.ru: Рахимов Нурали житель города Яван. Женат и имеет семерых детей. 14 лет занимается бизнесом в сфере торговли. Торгует тканями на центральном рынке города. Для того, чтобы ввезти сезонный товар хочет получить кредит , сроком на 18 месяцев.Кредит поможет ему увеличить товарооборот и привлечь новых клиентов.
texts.en:
Nurali R. lives in the city of Yavan. He is married and has seven children. For 14 years he has been working in sales. He sells fabric at the city's central market. He would like to receive a loan for import of seasonal goods. The loan term will be 18 months. The loan will help him increase sales and attract new customers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Import seasonal goods

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Medical Equipment, Patient Examination Couch, and Renovations

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.ru: Нурова Дилафруз проживает в городе Яван. Разведена. Живет одна с двумя детьми. Зарабатывает на жизнь , занимаясь торговлей. Имеет небольшой магазин , где торгует продуктами питания. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже5 лет. В данный момент ей необходимо завезти товар , для этого она решила получить кредит , сроком на 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Dilafruz N. lives in the town of Yavan. She is divorced and has two children. She earns her living in retail and owns a small grocery store. She has been in this business for 5 years. Currently, Dilafruz decided to obtain a 10-month loan in order to acquire new goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Hidayat Ghulam Mustafa Group

texts.en:
Hidayat baji is 47 years old, married, and the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son completed his education through 10th standard and started work as a building supervisor. Her daughters are in school.  Hidayat baji’s husband is a building contractor and provides construction materials to builders. He has been in this business for the past 15 years. Hidayat baji embroiders dresses at home and sells the in the market. Her daughters help her. She shares her earnings with her husband to meet the expenses of her household. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more construction supplies (beams, sand, and cement) for her husband. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Paveen Akhtar baji requests a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business. Shabana baji requests a loan to buy another snookertable for her snooker club. Sabran baji requests a loan to buy tools for her motor workshop. ZulaiK. baji requests a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies

loans.name: Grace Group

texts.en:
Rose M., 37, is a married mother of five children, aged six to 20. She is also the foster mother of her late brother’s three orphans. She rents a small stall in Kampala’s vibrant Owino market where she sells second-hand clothes and provides tailoring services. She became a seamstress five years ago after earning a certificate in tailoring. She specializes in gomeses (traditional dresses) and school uniforms.

This is Rose’s first loan with BRAC. She will use the loan proceeds to purchase wholesale quantities of clothing items for her boutique and to purchase more tailoring materials and supplies. She hopes that this loan will help her attract more customers with a higher selection of products and increase her profits.

Rose has big ambitions! She hopes to one day import clothing from Dubai and New York and offer them in her own exclusive boutique. She would love to be able to educate her children in the finest universities abroad.

loans.use: Purchase wholesale quantities of clothing

loans.name: Sona

texts.en: Sona is the mother of six children who lives in the village of Ahmad-Oba in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. She went into business for herself four years ago, and is applying for a loan of $1,200 to improve her business by buying more goods.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell to her customers

loans.name: Matluba

texts.ru: Раджабова Матлюба проживает в городе ДУшанбе. Возраст 46 лет. Имеет четверых детей. Имеет миниателье. Обратилась к нам за кредитом, для того, чтобы закупить две швейные машинки. Таким образом она увеличит состав ателье и сможет принять учениц. Это поможет населению пользоваться данными услугами. Кроме того она даст возможность обучаться молодым девочкам. Погасить кредит может в течение 15 месяцев.
texts.en:
Matluba R. lives in Dushanbe. She is 46 years old and has four children. She has a small tailor shop. She turned to us for a loan in order to buy two sewing machines. This will expand her shop so she can take on apprentices. Local residents will be better able to take advantage of the shop's services, and she will also be giving young women an opportunity to learn the trade. The loan will be repaid over 15 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of two sewing machines

loans.name: Kosar Parveen Chiragh Muhammad Group

texts.en:
Kosar Parveen baji is a 49 years old widow and a mother of two sons. Kosar baji struggled hard after the death of her husband. She worked day and night to give their children good education. She started sewing clothes for her neighbors, and then one of her neighbor made helped her contact a clothing factory. The factory owner gave her orders to sew trousers on weekly basis. She invested her earnings in her sons' education. Both her sons completed their education through the 10th standard, and now they both work. The youngest son started a plastic bead-selling business. He buys plastic beads from a factory and sells to different shops. Kosar baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more plastic beads to expand her son’s business. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shahla R. baji and Haleema baji and Irshad baji each request a loan to buy clothes for their clothes-selling business. Norseen baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy plastic beads wholesale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ameena M. Mushtaq Group

texts.en:
Ameena Baji is the wife of M. M. and lives in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 40 years. She is the mother of two sons. Both of her sons are drivers by profession. Ameena Baji is a seamstress and shares her earnings with her husband to meet the house expenses. Her husband is also a driver. They have a vehicle named “Shahzore” which they use to deliver (vegetables and fruits) from one place to another. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s vehicle.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Bashiran Baji wants loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Rasoolan Baji wants a loan to buy material (beads and colored thread and cloth) for her decorative embroidery business. Nusrat Baji wants a loan to buy tools to repair computers. Samia Kalsoom Baji wants a loan to buy a digital camera for her photo-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair her vehicle named "Shahzore"

loans.name: Nayyer Ishtiaq Hussain Khan Group

texts.en:
Nayyer baji is a wife of I. H. K. and resides in Pakpattan, Pakistan. She is 41 years old and a mother of three daughters. Her elder daughter sews clothes and completed her education through 10th standard. The other two are now in 10th standard. Nayyer baji’s husband grows vegetables on land he rents. He has been doing this work for the past 15 years. Nayyer baji is a seamstress and charges $3 per suit. She bears the expenses of her daughters' education and her husband bears the household expenses. They both are very happy to be dividing their responsibilities. Nayyer baji is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer for her husband so that he can increase his vegetable yield.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Gulshan baji requests a loan to buy material (leather and nails) for her shoe-making business. Zareen kosar baji requests a loan to buy furniture (chairs and tables) for her tuition center. Azizan baji requests a loan to buy animals (goats) to resell. Parveen baji requests a loan to buy another bicycle for her bicycle-selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to grow vegetables

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima M.hussain Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Fatima baji is a wife of M. and lives in Pakpattan, Pakistan. She is the mother of five sons. Her first three sons have a decorative embroidery business. They embroider dresses on order and charge $4 to $5 per dress. Her younger son is a driver and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Her youngest son is still in school. Ghulam Fatima baji’s husband makes plastic utensils and sells them in the market. Ghualm Fatima baji also helps her sons in the dress business. She is applying for a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread, cloth and sketches) for her son’s decorative embroider business. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Haleema sadia baji and Sakina baji each request a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Rukhsana baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Razia parveen baji requests a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for decorative embroidery dress business

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo lives in Ijaniki, Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO Microfinance client. Iyabo is a 58-year-old widow with 4 children. Iyabo sells charcoal for a living. She travels to Osun state twice every month to purchase bags of charcoal to resell in Lagos state. She is asking for a loan of N50 000 ($425) to purchase more bags of charcoal for resale. Iyabo has been in this business for a long time. Iyabo says thank you to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana is 38 years old. She is married and has 2 children. She owns a farm where she cultivates pumpkin, corn, and other vegetables. Nana is a LAPO Microfinance client. Nana is asking for a loan of N120,000 (S1025) to purchase pumpkin seeds to sow and insecticides to control pests on her farm. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pumpkin seeds and insecticides

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Marry is 48 years old. She is married and has 4 children. Mary is a farmer. Mary works on her farm every day of the week from 6:30 am to 4:00 pm. She cultivates pumpkin, corn, and other vegetables. Mary lives in Ketu, Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO Microfinance client. She is asking for a loan of N120,000 ($1025) to purchase pumpkin seeds to sow and insecticides to control pests. Mary says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pumpkin seeds and insecticides

loans.name: Masorie Progressive Union Group

texts.en:
This is Humu S. K., Fatmata K., Fatmata M., Brima M. and Adama K.. They named their group Masorie Progressive Union. They are local entrepreneurs from the village of Masorie. They sometimes come to Makeni, about fifteen miles from Masori, to sell their goods. This is the second time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previously, each one in the group received a loan of 500,000 LE. That loan created meaningful impacts in lives of these people. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are now requesting a loan of 700,000 LE each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Humu (right) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-eight years of age. She was born in the village called Sanda Taindarim about thirty miles from Makeni and fifteen miles from Masori. Today, she is married and living in Masori village. Her and her husband have two children, both of whom are attending schools in Freetown. Her husband serves as Section Chief for the people of Masori. His duties include hearing and settling minor disputes between members of the community.

Humu sells palm oil, rice and other locally produced items in the Masori village. She has been in this business for over ten years now. With this new loan, she will expand her business. She will be able to buy about ten to fifteen barters of palm oil (five gallons make up a barter). A barter of palm oil costs 30,000 LE. She will then choose to either sell in Masori village or take them to Makeni depending on the where she can get better profit.

To date, she has not encountered any great challenges worth noting. Business is doing well and she loves and enjoys it. To Humu and her colleagues in the group, an increase in profit means making their lives better. They will be able to take good care of their children, specifically with their educational and nutritional needs, as well as saving some for emergencies.

loans.use: To increase her stock of palm oil

loans.name: Victory

texts.en: Victory owns a farm where she grows pumpkin and other vegetables. Victory works on her farm every day of the week. She is a very hard-working woman. Victory is 35 years old and married. She has 3 children. Victory is a LAPO client. She is requesting a loan of N120,000 ($1025) to purchase pumpkin seeds and insecticides to control pests on her farm. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase pumpkin seeds and insecticides

loans.name: Matluba

texts.ru: Асоева Маьлюба проживает в Гиссарском районе в поселке Мирзо Ризо. Возраст 25 лет, не замужем. Обратилась к нам за кредитом для того, чтобы купить швейную машинку. Она недавно окончила курсы  шитья и поэтому решила открыть свое дело, то есть заняться пошивом национальной одежды на заказ. Ее бизнес поможет населению ее кишлака пользоваться данными услугами, не выезжая за приделы кишлака.
texts.en:
Matluba A. lives in the village of Mirzo Rizo in the Gissar District. She is 25 years old and unmarried. She came to us for a loan to buy a sewing machine. She recently finished studying sewing and so has decided to open her own tailoring business, making traditional clothing to order. Her business will provide village residents local access to these services.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine

loans.name: Annette Nannyonjo's Group

texts.en: Annette is a leader of a 5 member group.  She is 26 years old and is married with 4 children between the ages of 3 and 13. All of her children attend school. She resides and owns a two room house where she lives with eight people.  The house has electricity but it does not have piped water. Annette works selling second hand clothing in a semi- urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She sells to a an average of 20 customers per day and to all types of people including men, women and children. Annette has been operating this business for six years and has managed to improve her standard of living. Annette is now faced with the challenge of high transport costs from home to work.  Her monthly expenses includes rent, school fees and medication . She would like to use this loan to purchase some new clothes for resale.  Annette is also aspiring to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for resale.

loans.name: Babalola

texts.en: Babalola sells drinks in her shop and she has been in this business for the past 4 years. Babalola is a LAPO Microfinance client. Babalola lives in Kasidi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She opens her shop by 7am in the morning and she closes by 7pm daily. Babalola is 40 years old and married with 5 children. Babalola is requesting the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Aissa

texts.fr: Mariée et mere de six (06)enfants aissa est agée 48 ans elle s 'active dans la vente des huilles de palme  depuis 10 ans .Le produit est acheté par les femmes du quartier qui l utilisent dans la préparation des repas.Le pret denandé servira  à renforcer son fond de roulement par l 'achat de quantité plus importante de marchandise pour faire face à la forte demande des clients.
texts.en:
Aissa is 48 years old, married, and the mother of six children. She has been selling palm oil for 10 years. Palm oil is bought by neighbourhood women who use it in meal preparation. The loan will be used to bolster her working capital by purchasing more merchandise to meet the high demand of her customers.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Tamensusor Group

texts.en:
This is Alpha M., Kadiatu S., Sallay K., Hawa J. and Amie B.. They named their group Temensusor, a Temne word meaning "give us another try." They are local entrepreneurs in a village called Massori, about fifteen miles from Makeni City in northern Sierra Leone. This is the second time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previously, each one of them in the group received a loan of 500,000 LE. That loan created meaningful impacts in the lives of these borrowers. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Today, they are requesting a loan of 700,000 LE each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Alpha (right) is the leader of the group. She is twenty years of age. He was born in Massori. He is married with three children: one is in primary school, one is not yet of school age and the third is still waiting to be sent to school. His wife is a businesswoman. Alpha has been selling palm oil for three years now. With this new loan, he would like to invest it in rice as he senses that palm oil is becoming a scarce commodity thus making it very expensive to buy. Using his bicycle, he will go to the neighboring village of Magbenkia (two miles from Massori) to buy the rice. A bushel of rice costs him 25,000 LE and he will sell either in his village of Massori for 27,000 LE or in Makeni City, where he can sell for up to 30,000 LE.

Thus far, Alpha faces no serious challenge in his business worth noting. His business is going fine and well. He is very passionate about his business. To Alpha and colleagues in the group, an increase in profit means making their lives better. They will be able to take good care of their children, specifically with their educational and nutritional needs, as well as saving some for emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase rice for resale

loans.name: Shohsanam

texts.en:
H. Shohsanam is 38 years old. She is married and has five adorable children. She works hard in order to ensure them with the best future. Shohsanam has 14 years' experience preparing and selling confectionery. She began working with a friend delivering bread. With the money she saved in that activity, she decided to buy an oven and work as an independent with her husband. She works daily from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. preparing confectionary. The business is successful, and generates a stable income, allowing Shohsanam to support her family. 
Shohsanam wants the Kiva loan to be able to buy necessary products to prepare extra cookies, because at this time she is only supplying part of her demand. With this loan, she wants to expand her business, thus to be able to supply all of her customers and also to fix up the business to a better condition. With this purpose she requests 2500 Somoni ($750 US dollars) for the term of 4 months. Shohsanam would like to thank everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan with accuracy in time. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Shohsanam‘s business, and they will sincerely thank you.

loans.use: Purchasing necessary products for preparation of the extra cookies

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en: Bolaji is a 40-year-old married woman. She has 3 children. Bolaji sells foodstuffs like yams, elubo (yam flour), garri (cassava flour), and melon in her shop. She lives in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria. Bolaji works in her shop from Monday to Sunday. She has been in this business for a long time. Bolaji is asking for a loan of N100, 000 ($850) to increase the inventory she has on hand. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her shop

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
K. Firuza is an enterprising woman with a big desire of improving the quality of life of her family. She is a single mother of two children. Two years ago, she started offering her services as a seamstress to her neighbors and acquaintances. She began this business because she did not have a job and she needed to find an activity to support her children. She works in a tailoring shop where she produces national dresses for women.
