Now her children are going to kindergarten. She wishes her children to continue with their education. That is the reason that she needs to continue growing her business. 
She asks for a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900 USD) that will be invested in buying supplies to increase her production and cover her customers' demands. She commits herself to return the amount in 10 months. Help this family with improving the quality of their lives by contributing to the growth of Firuza’s business. They will sincerely thank you for it.

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics for sewing women national dresses.

loans.name: Komi

texts.en: Komi A. is a recently married man who runs a taxi-moto business.  He does not yet have children, but hopes to in the near future, after he has saved up enough money to provide for them.  Komi lives in Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo.  Because of Wome’s location, which is somewhat isolated, many residents of Wome take taxi-motos to nearby villages and Komi’s services are always in demand.  Komi picks up passengers along the road, as seen in this photo, and drops them off at their destination.  Kofi has hopes to use this loan from Kiva to buy a newer, more comfortable motorcycle, so that he may better serve his clients and earn more money.  With the profits he will earn from this improvement, Komla can better provide for his wife and save money for his future family

loans.use: Buy a new moto

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en: Omolara lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells yams, plastic containers, and coolers of different types and sizes. Omolara has been in this business for a long time. Omolara is 40 years old and married. She has 4 children. Omolara is a LAPO Microfinance client. She is asking for a loan of N100,000 ($825) to increase her inventory of yams, plastic containers, and coolers. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase yams, plastic containers, and coolers for resale

loans.name: Florence Namusisi’S Group

texts.en:
Florence, the leader of a five-member group, is a 37-year-old married woman with four children aged between 4 months and 14 years, three of whom go to school. She owns and resides in a two-roomed house that has neither electricity nor piped water. The family gets three meals a day and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Her monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

Florence operates a restaurant in her home, serving an average of 20 customers each day While she began this business four years ago and has managed to improve her standard of living, she has also started another business operating a bar to supplement her income. Both businesses, however, are hindered during rainy season, when it is difficult for her customers to patronize her enterprises due to disruptions in transportation, etc.

She is requesting this loan in order to buy a refrigerator and acquire electricity for her home. Florence is aspiring to eventually buy a plot of land upon which to operate her businesses, thereby eliminating the payment of rent.

loans.use: To buy a refridgerator and acquire electircity.

loans.name: Gulrukhsor

texts.en:
L. Gulrukhsor is a 29-year-old widower and mother. She does sewing work in a tailoring shop to earn money for her children. She started because Gulrukhsor loves this trade. Shortly after her husband passed away, this activity became her only income source to get the resources that her family needed. Gulrukhsor is doing all the best to ensure her children a good education and the best future. She wishes that her children can continue with their education. That is the reason that she needs to continue growing her business. 
She asks for a 4000 Somoni ($1200 US dollars) loan that will be invested in buying supplies to increase her production and cover her customers' demands. She commits herself to return the money in 10 months. Help this family with improving the quality of their lives by contributing to the growth of Gulrukhsor’s business. They will sincerely thank you for it.

loans.use: To purchase new modern fabrics for sewing the national dresses.

loans.name: Mathew Group

texts.en:
This is Isatu S., Fatu K. and Aminata K.. They named their group the Mathew Group. They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Makeni. This is the sixth time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previously, each one in the group received a loan of 1,000,000 LE. That loan created meaningful impact in the lives of these people. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Today, they are requesting a loan of 3,000,000 LE to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Isatu S. (left) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-five years of age. She was born in Makeni, north of Sierra Leone. She is married with three children. Two of her children are in secondary school and one is in primary school. Her husband is a businessman who sells second-hand clothes. Isatu sells both soft and hard drinks in Makeni City.

With this new loan, Isatu will expand on her business. She will be able to buy at least twelve crates of soft drinks, seven crates of beer, three crates of Battery energy drink and three crates of power shakes. She travels to Freetown, which is 390 miles round trip, to buy the drinks. The fare to and from Freetown is 20,000 LE each, and she pays 100,000 LE for the crates of drinks she buys. So far, Isatu faces no major challenge worth noting. Business is going fine for her and she loves doing it. Her immediate goal is to buy herself a plot of land so that she can build a house. She is tired of renting!

loans.use: To buy supplies of beverages for resale

loans.name: Bukola

texts.en: Bukola lives in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells weavons, hair extensions, and hair cream. Bukola is 23 years old and married with one child. Bukola has been in this business for the past 2 years. She works in her shop from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday to Sunday. Bukola hopes for a loan of N100, 000 ($850 USD) to purchase more inventory for her shop. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more weavons, hair extensions, and hair cream for her beauty salon

loans.name: Mahliyo

texts.en:
S. Mahliyo is 25 years old. She is living with her parents and two sisters. She is a well-known seamstress in her community, seeing that she has been working there for more than 7 years. Seven years ago, Mahliyo decided to take advantage of her reputation and bought a tailoring machine. Since then, she is providing tailoring services. The entrepreneur says that she now has a well-established clientele, the majority of whom are young girls who often order the national dresses. In this way, she constantly adds new clients and has seen her business grow. 
Now she is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900 USD) for the term of 10 months for purchasing new modern fabric for sewing the national dresses. You can help improve the quality of life of her family. Mahliyo and her family are grateful for your generosity and support.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new modern fabrics for sewing the national dresses.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine sells medicine and supplies in her pharmacy. She has been in this business for a long time. 

Josephine lives in Okoko, in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 32 years old and married. She has no children. 

Josephine is a LAPO Microfinance client. She will use the loan of 140,000 naira ($1200 USD) to purchase more medicine and provisions for resale. She says "thank you" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase medicine and provisions for resale

loans.name: Begam

texts.en:
T. Begam is 27 years old. She is a widow and has 5 children. When her husband passed away, she was left without a steady income. Supporting this large family on her own is very difficult. Begam has a grocery store where she sells sweets and candies of different types and tastes. She has been in this business for 8 years. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Begam is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy groceries again. 
Begam is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750 USD) for the term of 4 months to increase the inventory she has for sale. One of her dreams is that her children progress by means of their studies. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Begam reach all of her aspirations.

loans.use: Ingredients for increasing her food stock

loans.name: Ahliddin

texts.ru: Гайбуллоев Ахлиддин проживает в городе Душанбе. Имеет высшее образование . Но занимается частным предпринимательством. Арендует магазин , где торгует запасными частями для мобильных телефонов. Не женат , но живет в очень большой семье. Житвет с родителями, братьями и сестрами. Он является основным кормильцем семьи. Поэтому ему приходится  много работать для того, чтобы обеспечить cвою семью. Сейчас он хочет получить кредит для того, чтобы привезти товар и таким образом увеличить товарооборот. Срок на который он планирует взять кредит 18 месяцев.
texts.en:
Ahliddin G. lives in Dushanbe. He has a higher education and is engaged in private enterprise. He leases a store and sells spare parts for mobile phones. He is single, but comes from a very big family. He lives with his parents and siblings and is the sole provider for the family. He has to work a lot to support his family. Ahliddin wants to obtain an 18-month loan to acquire new goods and increase turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Manso Group

texts.en:
This is Fatmata K. and Hawa C.. They named their group Manso. This will be their fifth loan from SMT. The previous loans have had meaningful impacts in the lives of these people. The last loan they received from Kiva through SMT was for 800,000 LE each. Now they are requesting a loan of 1,000,000 LE each to enable them to further strengthen their businesses.

Fatmata K. (left) is the leader of the group. Fatmata is thirty-three years of age. She was born in Makeni City, in the Bombali District in northern Sierra Leone. She is married with two children, both of whom are in primary schools. Her husband is a tailor. The two work hard to sustain the family. Fatmata has been baking and selling bread for over four years now at the town’s main market. With this loan, Fatmata will reinvest the proceeds into her bread business. She will use the whole loan to buy bags of flour. A bag of flour costs her 140,000 LE in Makeni. She will be able to buy seven bags of flour with the loan. With the numerous loans she has received from Kiva through SMT, she was able to buy herself a manual machine to help her mix the flour very well.

With the profit she makes, Fatmata uses part of it to repay her monthly loan, part to feed herself and her children and the rest is saved for future use. Having repaid her loan successfully, it is her wish to buy herself a plot of land and prepare herself for the challenge of building a house.

loans.use: To buy at least seven bags of flour for her business

loans.name: Fumi

texts.en: Fumi sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs in her house. She has had this small business for a while. Fumi is 28 years old and married with two children. Fumi lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO Microfinance client. Fumi is requesting a loan of N100, 000 ($850 USD) to purchase more groceries to sell to customers. She says thank you to all the Kiva lenders for their financial support and to LAPO microfinance for their business training.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, drinks, and provisions to sell

loans.name: Tene United Group

texts.en:
This is Fatmata K. and Mabinty K.. They named their group Tene United, named after the home village of the group leader. They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Magburaka, about fifteen miles from Makeni City in northern Sierra Leone. This is the third time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previously, each one in the group received a loan of 500,000 LE. That loan created a meaningful impact in the lives of these people. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Today, they are requesting a loan of 800,000 LE each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Fatmata K. (right) is the leader of the group. She is forty-five years of age. She was born in Sanda about thirty miles from Makeni and forty miles from Magburaka. Marriage brought her to Magburaka town, where today she has her business. She is married with six children. Five of her children are in secondary school and one is in primary school. Her husband is a school teacher in one of the schools in Magburaka. Fatmata sells clothes in Magburaka town market. With this new loan, she will expand on her business. She will use this loan to buy a bale of cotton. She travels either to Freetown or neighboring Guinea to buy the clothes she sells. In Freetown, a bale of wax cotton costs her 1,400,000 LE and a piece of dried cotton costs her 14,000 LE.

Sometimes, within a bale of cotton, there are torn pieces. This brings losses to Fatmata and poses a great challenge to her. Apart from this, she faces no major challenges and likes the business she is doing very much. To Fatmata and colleagues in the group, an increase in profit means making their lives better. They will be able to take good care of their children, specifically with their educational and nutritional needs, as well as putting some money aside for emergencies.

loans.use: To buy at least a bale of cotton for her business

loans.name: Sidik

texts.en:
A. Sidik is 36 years old. He is married with two children. Sidik is a very diligent and hard-working man. He provides a taxi service. Sidik’s usual itinerary is the Kanibadan-Khujand. For the last three years the current business had been the main income for the family, allowing Sidik to improve the living conditions of his large family. Currently, his daily profit is about 150-200 Somoni. 
Besides his wife and children he is also supporting his parents. Like any business, Sidik's business requires an investment from time to time. Now the car needs to be thoroughly fixed. For this reason Sidik requests 2500 Somoni ($750 USD) for the term of 9 months. Sidik promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all supporting him.

loans.use: Thorough fixing of the vehicle used for providing of taxi services.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther sells kerosene and rechargeable phone cards, and makes phone calls for people in her shop. Esther works from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. and has owned this business for 8 years. Esther lives in Jakunde, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO Microfinance client. Esther is requesting a loan amount of N140, 000 ($1200 USD) to purchase more kerosene and rechargeable phone cards to sell. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene and rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Monica Nsugwa’S Group

texts.en:
Monica is a leader of a 4-member loan group. She is 30 years old and is married with 3 children between the ages of 2 and 10 years. Two of her children go to school. Monica takes care of two of her sister’s children and her elderly mother.  

She rents and resides and rents a two-room house where she is staying with six people. They have neither  electricity nor piped water at home The family gets three meals a day and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. 

Monica sells new clothes in mobile markets. She sells to an average of 15 customers each day and uses public transport to get to and from work. Monica started with this same business seven years ago and has managed to improve her standard of living. Monica sells to all categories of customers, mainly on a retail basis.  

Monica is faced with a transportation challenge because of bus delays. Her monthly expenses include school fees,  medication, and feeding the family.  She wants to use this loan to buy more clothes and aspires to seeing her business grow bigger so that she can own a permanent workplace.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Abdumanon

texts.en:
A. Abdumanon is 41 years old. He is married with three children. Abdumanon has been processing and selling dried apricots at the local market for 12 years. His wife is a housekeeper. He has a higher education and works at a hydro-metallurgical factory in Isfara town. 

The wages that earns from his job are not enough for his family's consumption, so, on weekends, he sells dried apricots at the local market. This business allows him to earn enough money to care for his children and provide them with an education. In addition, as is customary, every year during the Kurban festival, he sacrifices a sheep and divides it among the poor. 

His wife and his children help him with processing the dried apricots at his house. Today, because of the season, he wants to expand his business and purchase more dried apricots. He is asking for a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900 USD) for a term of 9 months. He wants to buy more dried apricots in order to process them, and to sell during market times. Be an important part of the growth of Abdumanon’s business.

loans.use: To buy dried apricots to sell

loans.name: Gaibullo

texts.ru: Баротов Гайбулло житель города Душанбе. Женат . Имеет одного сына. Имеет автомашину "Opel" , которую использует  для частного такси. Он работает в центре города. Но в связи с тем , что цены на бензин растут , ему необходимо установить газовое оборудование. Поэтому он обратился к нам за кредитом. Он запрашивает 1200 долларов США.сроком на 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Gaibullo B. lives in the city Dushanbe with his wife and son. He uses his Orel brand car as a private taxi in the city's downtown. Because gas prices are rising, he wants to install a natural gas-based fuel system in his car. To do this he came to us for a loan. He is requesting 1200 dollars, to be repaid in 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installation of natural gas fuel system

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en:
Wissam is a 21-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife. Wissam owns a clothing shop, where he sells women's and men's clothes, as well as some accessories. He has been in this business for two years now. Wissam requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase the new clothing collection. The loan will help him buy clothes for the “Eid”. 

Wissam didn’t experience deficulties in opening his store because he used to work with people who taught him the business, and also he had his family support which pushed him and encouraged him to open his clothing shop. His future plan is to expand his business.

loans.use: Wissam needs the loan to purchase clothes for his shop

loans.name: Dasolatu

texts.en: Dasolatu lives in Igbelerin, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells kitchen utensils and baby clothes. Dasolatu is 40 years old and married with two children. Dasolatu has been in this business for 1 year. She would like a loan of N100, 000 ($850 USD) to purchase more kitchen utensils and baby clothes for her shop. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more kitchen utensils and baby clothes to sell

loans.name: Akinyara

texts.en: Akinyara sells drinks and provisions in her shop. Akinyara has been in this business for a long time. Akinyara is 46 years old and married with 3 children. Akinyara lives in Igbelerin, Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO Microfinance client. Akinyara needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Pas A Die Group

texts.en:
This is Fullamus B. and Marie K.. They named their group Pass a Die. They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Magburaka, about fifteen miles from Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. This is the third time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previous loans have had large impacts on the lives of these borrowers. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. They are requesting a loan of 800,000 LE each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Fullamusu (right) is the leader of the group. She is fifty-five years of age. She was born in Magburaka town. She is a widow with eight children, most of whom are now grown-ups and can look after themselves. She currently has four children still going to school. Fullamusu sells local produces like palm oil, rice and other market foods. With this new loan, Fulllamussu will expand her business and travel to villages surrounding Magburaka, such as Makali and Masingbim, where she buys the palm oil and other goods she sells.

loans.use: To buy palm oil to expand her business

loans.name: Mahmud

texts.en:
G. Mahmud is 35 years old. He is married with 4 children of school age. His wife is a housekeeper, and she is taking care after their children. Thus Mahmud is the main breadwinner in the family. Mahmud’s children are small now, but already today he is working hard in order to ensure the best future for them. 
For more than 20 years Mahmud is baking the national bread “lepeshka.” He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonal lows. He gets up early and bakes lepeshka and bread so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. All the ingredients like flour, salt, and yeast he purchases in the local market. Now Mahmud requests 4000 Somoni ($1200 US dollars) for the term of 12 months. The loan shall be spent for purchasing flour and coal for baking the lepeshka. Mahmud has already had one loan and demonstrated himself as an honest client and he promises to repay the current loan promptly as well.

loans.use: Purchasing flour for baking the national bread “lepeshka”

loans.name: Ramzo

texts.en: Ramzo Hojievais 48 years old and has three children.  For over six years, Ramzo has owned a specialized fabrics store in the central market of Isfara, where she produces traditional dresses that are commonly used in dowries throughout Tajikistan.  Through hard work, perseverance, and the application of her integrity, Ramzo's fabrics store has become one of the leading fabrics vendors in the market where she works.  But Ramzo is an ambitious businesswomen and would like to increase her profits and thereby save enough money to put her children through school.  Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $1000, which she will use to increase her inventory of fabrics.

loans.use: To purchase a wide variety of fabrics for making dresses.

loans.name: Safarali

texts.ru: Раджабов Сафарали житель города Душанбе. Женат . Имеет четверых детей. Работает таксистом на частной автомашине.Работает так уже пять лет. Старший сын закончил Вуз. Теперь они вместе планируют сыграть свадьбу. То есть он пришел к нам за получением кредита. Деньги он планирует использовать на проведение свадьбы. Выплачивать кредит будет из своего заработка .Погашать кредит сможет в течение трех месяцев.
texts.en:
Safarali R. lives in the city of Dushanbe. He is married and has four children. For the past five years he has been working as a private taxi driver. His oldest son has finished college, and now the two are planning to put on a wedding. That is the reason he is asking for a loan. They plan to use the money for wedding expenses. The loan will be repaid from his income, over a period of three months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for the wedding of a son

loans.name: Taborakkhon

texts.en: Taborakkhon J. is 37 years old, married, and has three children.  She works hard in the market of Isfara city selling fabric for traditional Tajikistani dress.  Taborakkhon's husband helps her with their business, because she is often busy helping their children study (her husband is pictured).  Taborakkohn and her husband have agreed that their business will attract more customers and earn more profits if they offer a wider range of products.  They also specifically hope to make their business appealing to people who earn a wide range of incomes.  In order to attain more products and increase the inventory of her business, Taborakkhon is requesting a loan of $1000.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and other products.

loans.name: Anta Mbaye

texts.fr: Cette dame agée de 55 ans  mere huit (08) enfant est veuve .Elle vit avec ses enfants et petits enfants .Pour survenir à ses besoins ;elle fait de la broderie à la main en fabriquant des draps de lit qu 'elle vend  aux femmes du quartier depuis le decé de son marie il y a trois (3) ans.Dans le cadre  du renforcement de ses activités ,elle a déjà bénéficié d'un premier de la caisse .Le pret sollicité  aujourd'hui lui permettra de satisfaire  à la livraison d'une commande de draps faite par une association de femmes du quartier.
texts.en:
This woman, age 55, is a mother with eight children and a widow. She lives with her children and grand-children. To provide for their needs, she does embroidery by hand and makes bedsheets that she has been selling to women of the district since her husband's death three years ago. In regards to bolstering her business, she has already been the recipient of an initial bank loan. The loan she is requesting today will enable her to deliver on an order of bedsheets made for a women's association in the district.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating funds

loans.name: Koffi

texts.en:
Koffi B. is a 28-year-old married man. Koffi lives in Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. 

He does not have any children because he does not yet have the means to provide for them, but he has started a taxi-moto business to improve his financial situation. Koffi picks up passengers along the road with his motorcycle, as seen in this photo, and drops them off at their destination. 

In this photo, Koffi is just outside of Wome, near Togo’s border with Ghana. With this loan from Kiva, Koffi hopes to continue to buy gas for his moto and to maintain it, as prices and demand for his services continue to rise. With the profits he will earn from his business, Koffi can better provide for his wife and save money for his future family.

loans.use: Buy gas and maintain motorcycle

loans.name: Die

texts.fr: Agé e de quarante cinquant (45) DIE F. est une femme mariée mére de cinq (05) enfants .Son activité principale est le commerce de mercerie surtout de fils à coudre .elle a installé sa boutique à côté des tailleurs ce qui lui permet de faire un chiffre d' affaire journalier assez important.Elle bénéficie d'une longue experience de plus de 8 ans dans le domaine. son histoire de credit avec la caisse date de plus d'un an .les fêtes de fin d'année etant une periode de forte activité pour les tailleurs la demande en fils est tres importante pour satisfaire à cette demande elle sollicite un pret.
texts.en:
Ms. F. DIE is 45 years old and a married mother of five. Her main business is in dressmaking supplies, especially thread. She has set up her boutique next to tailoring shops. This allows her to achieve fairly large sales figures each day. She benefits from lengthy experience, on the order of 8 or more years in this domain. Her credit history with the savings bank goes back over a year's time. With the year-end holidays being a time of good business for tailors, the demand for thread is quite high. To meet this demand, she is requesting a loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating funds

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth sells undergarments and sarongs in her shop. Elizabeth travels to Ghana once in a month to purchase more inventory to sell in Lagos. Elizabeth has been in this business for a long time and her shop is open from Monday to Sunday. Elizabeth is 38 years old and married with two children. Elizabeth requests a loan of N50,000 ($425 USD) to enable her to buy more sarongs and underwear. She thanks all of you who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and undergarments to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort sells groceries in her shop. She has been in this business for a long time. Comfort has a good relationship with her customers and this has attracted more customers to her store. Comfort is 50 years old and married with five children. Comfort is requesting a loan of N50,000 ($425 USD) to purchase more foodstuffs, provisions, and drinks to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane sells juice and drinks in wholesale and retail to her customers. Jane is 40 years old and married with four children. Jane is a LAPO Microfinance client. Jane is requesting a loan of N100,000 ($425 USD) to increase her inventory. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more juice and drinks to sell

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy lives in Agbara, Lagos State, Nigeria, Joy is 28 years old and married with two children. Joy is very happy because the festive season is fast approaching and the demand for her clothes will be high. Joy is a LAPO Microfinance client. She is requesting a loan amount of N100,000 ($850 USD) to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria owns a restaurant where she sells cooked food and has owned this business for a long time. Victoria is 48 years old and married with nine children. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 ($425 USD) to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell to her customers. Victoria is a LAPO Microfinance client. Victoria says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Nofisouth

texts.en: Nofisouth is 30 years old and married with three children. Nofisouth sells drinks and she is also a fashion designer. She lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO Microfinance client. Nofisouth hopes for a loan of N 70,000 ($600 USD) to purchase more drinks and tailoring materials to sell. She is grateful to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Foluke

texts.en:
Foluke is 35 years old. She is married and has three children. She lives in Alabarago, Lagos state, Nigeria.

Foluke sells garri (cassava flour) and palm oil. She travels to Imo state and Edo state to purchase palm oil and garri, and she resells the goods in Lagos state. She is asking for a loan of 70,000 naira ($600) to purchase more bags of garri and gallons of palm oil. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase garri and palm oil

loans.name: Mutiate

texts.en: Mutiate sells drinks in her shop. She has been in this business for a long time. Mutiate is a LAPO Microfinance client. She is 33 years old and married with 3 children. Mutiate lives in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of N70,000 ($600) to purchase soft drinks to sell in her shop. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Jackeline Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Jackelline V., trabajo desde muy joven en diferentes instituciones como asalariada, y a pesar de su corta edad, con sus ahorros pudo comprar un terreno en la zona sur de La Paz. Tiempo despues decide formar su familia, por lo cual deja de trabajar para dedicarse integramente a su hogar para atender además a un hijo con problemas de salud; es así que con el fin de lograr ingresos para construir su casa, decide aportar a la familia con otro tipo de ingresos abre su negocio de repostería vendiendo, empanadas, berlines, queques y tortas.
Es así como empieza a vender sus productos en la zona sur de la ciudad de La Paz, Bolivia, y actualmente es muy conocida en la zona.
texts.en:
Jackelline V. has worked since she was young in different institutions as a salaried employee. Despite her young age, with her savings, she was able to purchase some land in the area south of La Paz. Later, she decided to start a family for which she left work to dedicate herself to her home and to attend also to her child who has health problems. Lacking money to build a house, she decided to support her family with another type of income: she opened a bakery business selling empanadas, Berliners, and cakes. In this way, she began selling her products in the area south of the city of La Paz, Bolivia and currently, she is well known in the area.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: An increase in capital.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy T. is a 40-year-old married woman, and she has three children. She owns and operates a grocery shop in her neighborhood, where she sells items such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, and powdered milk.

She is now seeking a loan because she wants to increase her shop's inventory by purchasing additional bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, and boxes of body and hair creams. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children in school.

Mercy belongs to the community group known as the God is Good Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To increase her grocery store's inventory by purchasing additional rice, sugar, vegetable oil, creams, etc.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: La sra.Francisca se dedica desde hace 15 años a la venta de café, te, leche y sandwiches, en la calle Sagárnaga, una zona muy comercial de la ciudad. Vive en la Av. Las Delicias de la zona de Villa Fátima. de la ciudad de La Paz. Es viuda desde hace mucho tiempo por lo que ella sola se dedica a la crianza de su hija, quien le ayuda en el negocio y también en los quehaceres de la casa. El crédito será invertido en la compra de insumos para le venta de café y también invertirá en comprar productos para la venta durante las fiestas de fin de año. Es cliente muy responsable y puntual.
texts.en:
For 15 years, Francisca has sold coffee, tea, milk and sandwiches on Sagárnaga Street, a big commercial district in the city. She lives on Las Delicias Avenue in Villa Fátima, near the city of La Paz. She has been a widow for a long time and is solely responsible for raising her daughter, who helps with the business and the household chores. The loan will be invested in the purchase of supplies for the coffee shop and merchandise to sell at the end of the year festivities. She is very responsible and punctual.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita A. is a 28-year-old married woman with three children, all of whom are in school. She is a very resourceful wife and mother whose hard work brings a great deal to her family. Specifically, Rita supports her husband in providing for the household by working as a trader: she sells used shoes and ladies' slippers to earn a profit. Indeed, there is a big market for used shoes and slippers in Ghana because new shoes/slippers are too expensive for the country's poor people. Accordingly, selling used shoes and slippers is a niche market for many women like Rita to get involved in. Rita now seeks a loan to increase her business' inventory by purchasing additional used shoes and slippers. She believes the loan proceeds would enable her to pay for her children’s education and to rent a store for her trading business.

She is member of the group known as the God is Good Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To increase her trading business' inventory by purchasing additional used clothing and shoes and to rent a store

loans.name: Nelly Elizabeth

texts.es: La Sra. Nelly, casada, con 30 años de edad y 2 hijas, 1 del primer matrimonio y la otra del 2do, ambas estudian la primeria, tiene 7 años de trabajar para la Alcaldia de Juigalpa, es técnica en Administracion de Empresas, esta solicitando su 3er credito para cambiar el techo de su dormitorio que está ubicado al fondo de la casa de su mamá, comprara  perlines y zinc ya que esta construido con madera y zinc, los que estan en malas condiciones. Ella tiene un terreno y en el futuro piensa hacer un credito mayor para ir poco a poco construyendo su propia casa para el futuro de sus hijas.  Sus creditos anteriores los ha cancelado con responsabilidad y espera continuar manteniendo su buen record crediticio, porque piensa que los mas grande que debe tener una persona es honradez y credibilidad; su esposo trabaja fuera de la ciudad pero aporta al hogar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nelly Elizabeth M. A. is thirty years old, married, and has two daughters – one from her first marriage and the other from her second – who are in elementary school. Nelly Elizabeth has worked in the mayor's office in Juigalpa for seven years and works in Business Administration. She is requesting her third loan in order to redo the ceiling of her bedroom in the back of her mother's house. She will buy purlins (support beams) and zinc for the ceiling that is already made of wood and zinc, which are in poor condition. She has a plot of land and she is thinking of getting a bigger loan so that, bit by bit, she can build her own house for the future of her two daughters. She has paid off her previous loans responsibly and hopes to continue to maintain her good credit record, because she thinks that the biggest things a person should have are integrity and credibility; her husband works outside the city but contributes to the home.

Translated from Spanish by HannahLily P, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair a room (replace roofing)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Medical Equipment, Bed Linens, Sterilizer, and Water Pipes

loans.name: Diega Salvadora

texts.es: La profesroa Diega Salvadora, casada, de 49 años de edad, maestra de educacion primaria del Colegio San Francisco de Asis de Juigalpa, con 27 años de servicio, esta solicitando su 9no credito, el que utilizara para la reparacion de su cocina, cambiando el techo y 2 ventanas que tienen solo las verjas; tiene 2 hijos, 1 niña de 16 años y 1 varon de 10 años, ambos estudian la secundaria y primaria respectivamente.   La profesora durante los creditos anteriores que ha manejado con AFODENIC siempre ha pagado en tiempo y forma, siendo una cliente con la calificacion "A", manifiesta que se siente muy satisfecha con la atencion que se le ha brindado, donde ha tenido la oportunidad de ir mejorando su vivienda y resolviendo otras situaciones que se le han presentado.  Ella siempre recomienda a sus compañeras de trabajo que visiten AFODENIC y que no se comprometan con otras financieras, ya que las politicas de esta institucion son especiales para las y los asalariados.
texts.en:
Diega Salvadora, a schoolteacher for 27 years, married, 49 years old, an elementary teacher at the "Colegio San Francisco de Asis" in Juigalpa, is requesting her 9th loan to be spend on repairing her kitchen, changing the roof and 2 windows with only grille. She has two children, a 16 year-old daughter in high school and a 10 year-old boy in elementary. Her previous loans from AFODENIC were always paid correctly , she is an "A" grade client and she is very satisfied with the atention she has received, having had the opportunity to improve her dwelling and resolve other situations as well. She is always recommending her colleagues to visit AFODENIC and not make commitments with other financial companies as this institution's policies are special for salary-earners.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair kitchen

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice M. is a 40-year-old woman. She is divorced and the mother of two kids. Currently, the kids are in school. She lives with her kids in Odumase, a suburb of Koforidua in the Eastern region of Ghana. Beatrice loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. She has traded in maize and sweet potato in Odumase market for three years. She treks to the farming communities around Koforidua to purchase stock and retail it to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick up enough stock to make enough profit to support her family.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk of maize and sweet potatoes to enable her to scale up sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her kids in school. She is member of the group called God is Good Trust Group. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of maize and sweet potatoes.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet B. is a 48-year-old married woman with two children, one of whom is in school. For the past 10 years, Janet has been selling frozen foods at the local market of Koforidua, including chicken, pork, mutton, fish, and other meats.

Unfortunately, she does not have adequate capital to support her business at this time, especially due to increasing food prices. As such, she is seeking a loan so that she can purchase more cartons of frozen foods (e.g., fish, chicken, pork, and other meats) to increase her sales and to thereby generate additional revenue. Janet belongs to the community group known as the God is Good Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To generate an increase in sales while food prices are high by purchasing additional food (e.g., fish and meats)

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary T. is a 44-year-old married woman with two children, both of whom are in school. She owns and operates a grocery shop in her neighborhood, where she sells items such as sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, pastries (which she proudly states that she prepares herself), powdered milk, and biscuits.

She is now seeking a loan because she would like to increase her store's inventory by purchasing more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, and boxes of biscuits. In turn, she hopes to increase her savings to support her children while they are in school.

Mary belongs to the community group known as the God is Good Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To increase her store's inventory by purchasing additional foodstuffs (e.g., assorted drinks, sugar, bottled mineral water, and biscuits)

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank T. Nanor is a 40-year-old married man with a 15-year-old child. He is a pharmacist by trade, and he sells various kinds of drugs in his neighborhood such as blood tonic, pain killers, and malaria drugs. He notes that many local people patronize his store for first aid and so that he can cure them when they are sick.

He is now seeking a loan to meet his customers' demands by buying additional supplies of drugs, including certain drugs that he does not carry yet which are frequently sought by his customers. As a result, he hopes to generate an increase in his income to better support his family.

He is a member of the community known as the God is King Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand his inventory and to meet his customers' demands by purchasing additional drugs

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac N. is a 40-year-old married man with three children, all of whom are in school. He owns and operates a grocery shop in his neighborhood, where he sells items such as sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, pastries, powdered milk, and biscuits.

He is now seeking a loan so that he can increase his store's inventory by purchasing more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, and boxes of biscuits. In turn, he hopes to increase his savings to support his children while they are in school.

Isaac belongs to the Trust group known as the God is Good Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To increase his store's inventory by purchasing additional foodstuffs (e.g., assorted drinks, sugar, bottled mineral water, and biscuits)

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu F. is a 40-year-old divorced mother of two kids, both of whom are in school. She lives with her kids in Ashaiman, a suburb of Tema in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. Ramatu loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. More specifically, for the past 8 years, she has been trading goods such as maize, groundnuts, and millet in the Ashaiman market. Notably, she treks to Yendi (in the northern part of Ghana) to purchase her goods in bulk from farmers, and she then resells such goods to her customers. 

Unfortunately, she does not have an adequate amount of working capital to purchase enough goods to generate sufficient profits to support her family. As such, she is seeking a loan to purchase additional goods (e.g., maize, groundnuts, millet, and sweet potatoes) in bulk and to thereby increase her sales. In fact, she believes the loan would enable her to save enough money to support her kids in school. 

Ramatu is a member of the group known as the God is Good Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To increase her sales by purchasing additional goods in bulk (e.g., maize and sweet potatoes)

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina S. is 56 years old. She is divorced and the mother of two kids. Currently, the kids are in school. She lives with her kids in Ashaiman, a suburb of Tema in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. Amina is an achiever and a resourceful mother. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. She has traded in maize, groundnuts, millet, etc. in Ashaiman market for eight years. She treks to Tamale in the northern part of Ghana to purchase bulk stock from farmers and retail it to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick up enough stock to make enough profit to support her family.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk load of beans, groundnuts, millet and sweet potatoes to enable her to scale up her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her kids in school. She is member of the group called God is Good Trust Group. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. She does not sell on days of her group meeting and her picture was taken during her group meeting

loans.use: To purchase bulk of maize and sweet potatoes.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys K. T. is a hard-working businesswoman. She is 51 years old, and she is married with six children. For a living, she trades in fresh rice and sugar. To do so, she purchases her supply of rice and sugar from wholesale vendors in Tema (around the fishing harbor), and she later resells such goods to her customers.

She enjoys operating her business very much, but she says that commodity prices and transportation costs have gone up in recent months due to the current fuel crisis. As a result, her business has taken a hit because her working capital is inadequate to purchase appreciable quantities to sell. Therefore, she is now seeking a loan to inject additional capital into her business to enable her meet the demands of the marketplace. Specifically, she wants to use the loan proceeds to increase her stock of rice and sugar and to thereby increase her profits. In turn, Gladys hopes to accumulate more savings in order to pay for her children's education fees.

She is a member of the community group known as the Angel Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell on days when her group meets, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing additional goods

loans.name: Esse

texts.en: Esse N. is 36 years old and a married mother of 3 children (her youngest daughter is pictured in this photo.) Esse lives and works in Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital.  To provide for her family, Esse runs a hair salon in Wome.  Like many hairdressers in Togo, she specializes in ‘tresses,’ a popular African hairstyle of braids made with synthetic hair.  With her loan Esse would like to buy more hair products and tresses to satisfy her customers.  Esse also hopes to buy a new mirror.  With these purchases she hopes to increase her sales to be able to raise her quality of life and contribute to the expenses of children.

loans.use: Buy more hair products and tresses to satisfy her customers.

loans.name: Josiah

texts.en:
Josiah T. is a 36-year-old married man with one child. For the past 2 years, he has been a local producer of packaging materials. Josiah is a young man with a vision to serve humanity with his talent and skills, and he dreams of a well-established company of his own that would produce bulk packaging materials to serve all kinds of purposes. He produces and supplies his packaging materials to food vendors, market sellers, and super market operators so that they can wrap their customers' purchased items.

However, Josiah is constrained by inadequate capital, so he is unable to generate his packaging materials on a large scale to meet the demands of his customers. Thus, he is seeking a loan to buy a large quantity of rubber as well as a machine in order to increase his production and to thereby meet his customers' demands.

He belongs to the community group known as the Angel Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay his or her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. He notes that he does not sell any packaging materials on days when his group meets, and that his picture was taken during his group meeting.

loans.use: To increase production and to meet his customers' demands by purchasing a large quantity of rubber and a machine

payments.comment: retraction of repayment id 10235695
retraction of repayment id 10235697

loans.name: Arche De Noe Group

texts.en: Leontine started her business in 1981 and has been a faithful client with Hope DRC (a microfinance program) since February 2008. Over the years, Leontine has acquired solid experience in business. She first began selling sacs of corn, peanuts and beans, until 2005 when she had an accident on a boat and was hospitalized for three months. After the recovery, Leontine decided to change the business because of a broken finger that she got from the accident.  She opened a general boutique in late 2005 and has been operating this business to the present day. She sells soaps, sugar, salt, milk, toilet papers, oil, cans, and other household goods. Her business strategies are based on the high quality of goods, strategic pricing, caring for clients and never running out of inventory. With her next loan she is planning to rent a place to move her business indoors in order to avoid the heavy rains. Her dream is to purchase a boat in order to serve rural people as river transport. Leontine is married and a mother of four children.

loans.use: To rent a place to move the business indoors in order to avoid the heavy rains

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Abdoul  Aziz

texts.fr: Agé  de 22 ans  Abdoul aziz a apres les études primaire quitté l 'école pour se consacrer à l'élevage de la volail .IL est l'un des fournisseurs de viande de volail du quartier . avec le pret sollicité il va renforcer ses capacites de production.
texts.en:
Abdoul Aziz is 22 years old and left school after elementary school in order to dedicate himself to raising poultry. He supplies poultry meat to his district. He will use this loan to increase his production capabilities.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Veronica

texts.es:
En el mercado La Terminal de la ciudad de León la señora Veronica C. desde hace 15 años se ha dedicado a su negocio de elaboración y venta de comida el cual es comercializada todos los días desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana. Se caracteriza por ser una excelente cocinera ya que ha logrado acaparar varios clientes que le visitan diariamente.

Con el compromiso de atender a dichos clientes, la señora Veronica al ver la necesidad de adquirir la materia prima para preparar los alimentos ha decidido acudir a Ceprodel para obtener un crédito que le permita la compra de dicha materia prima para elaborar los alimentos y continuar atendiendo su negocio.
texts.en:
For the past fifteen years Veronica C. has run her own food production business in La Terminal – a market in the city of León that is open very early in the morning every day. She is known as an excellent cook and has succeeded in attracting several customers who come to her daily. With the commitment to serve said clients, Veronica sees the need to acquire raw material to prepare the food and has decided to go to Ceprodel to get a loan that will allow her to purchase said raw material to produce food and continue to serve her clients.

Translated from Spanish by HannahLily P, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

loans.name: Khary

texts.fr: Khary  est agée de 39 ans elle est mariée et mere de plusieurs enfants son activité principale est la vente de tissus teintés "thioup" tres prisés par les femmes sénégalaises.les revenus tirés de cette activité qu 'elle meme depuis plus de 4ans lui permet d 'entretenir ses enfants .elle sollicite un pret pour augmenter ses marchandises .
texts.en:
Khary is 39 years old, married, and the mother of several children. Her main business involves selling dyed 'thioup' cloth that is highly prized by Senegalese women. The income derived from this work, which she has been doing for over four years, enables her to care for her children. She is requesting a loan to augment her merchandise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating funds

loans.name: Blanca Azucena

texts.es:
La señora Blanca M. se dedica al negocio de venta de frutas en el mercado La Terminal de León. Ella se dedica con mucho esfuerzo a su negocio desde hace 20 largos años el cual ha venido desarrollando en su tramo y con la visión de crecer y expandirse para obtener mejores ingresos para mejorar el nivel de vida de sus hijos ya que es madre soltera.  

Por esta razón es que la señora M. ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito el cual será utilizado en la compra de los perecederos como lo son las naranjas. Es importante destacar que ella espera confiadamente en que Ceprodel le brindará el préstamo y así saldrá adelante en su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Blanca M. sells fruit at the market "La Terminal de León". She has maintained and developed her business with much effort for 20 long years and has the vision to grow and expand in order to obtain a higher income to improve the life quality of her children as she is a single mother.

For this reason, Mrs. M. has sought support from Ceprodel to get the benefit of a loan to be spent on the purchase of perichable goods such as oranges. It is important to point out that she trustfully expects Ceprodel to give her the loan and thus enable her to move ahead with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits

loans.name: Esperanza Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Esperanza del Socorro L. es originaria de la ciudad de León y se desempeña en la atención de su propia pulpería ubicada en el mercado La Terminal donde es visitada por varios clientes que hacen uso de los productos que ella ofrece.  

Sus inicios fueron muy difíciles por la razón de que vendía pocos productos pero  a medida que el tiempo ha venido transcurriendo ha logrado mejorar su condición económica y esto gracias al apoyo que le ha brindado Ceprodel el cual por medio de los créditos ha adquirido su mercadería para su comercialización. Hoy en día espera que su crédito sea otorgado para continuar con el negocio de pulpería.
texts.en:
Esperanza del Socorro L. is from the city of León. She is paying back the debt on her general store in the La Terminal market. Her store is frequented by many customers who make use of the products that she offers. Initially, business was tough because she sold so few products. Over time, she has managed to improve her economic situation, thanks to the support of Ceprodel. With the loans she has received, she has purchased more merchandise for her store. She hopes to be granted a loan so she can move ahead with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for the general store

loans.name: Jose Lenin

texts.es:
El señor José Lenin V. R. tiene la edad de 53 años, su estado civil es soltero, tiene 22 hijos de los cuales 8 hijos todavía dependen de el pero cada uno trabaja por cuenta propia, en sus propósitos esta el mantener su negocio para que los ingresos de estos le puedan ayudar para el día de mañana ya que todavía tiene algunos hijos que están muy pequeños y necesita encaminarlos para la vida para que de esta forma no pasen necesidad para el día de mañana por lo que también quiero ayudarlos para que tengan un futuro de estudios.



El tiempo que tiene de tener este negocio es de 30 años, la actividad económica a la que Don José Lenin se dedica es la venta y elaboración de ataúdes, el empieza este negocio por la necesidad de tener un trabajo que le ayudara a salir adelante con todos sus hijos por lo que decide aprender este oficio en un taller por cuenta propia y mas tarde que el decide instalar su propio negocio para sufragar los gastos de sus familia, el nos dice que fue difícil aprender esta profesión pero se convirtió en medio por el cual el pudiera salir adelante  es por eso el motivo del financiamiento destinado hacia el capital de trabajo por lo que tiene que comprar diferentes productos para la elaboración de los ataúdes como lo es: madera, pega, clavos, lija, pintura y un material llamado formica que es necesario para el toque final de sus productos por lo que tiene que viajar algunas veces para la compra de este material agradece la mano amiga que le brindo Fundación y otras organizaciones  en estos momentos debido a la difícil situación por la que el país pasa actualmente.
texts.en:
Mr. José Lenin V. R. is 53 years old, single, and has 22 children, 8 of which are still dependents, but the children all have jobs. He wants to keep running his business so his income can help in the future, as he still has some children who are very young and he needs to point them in the right direction in life so they do not fall on hard times. He also wants to help them have future education. He has run his business for 30 years. Mr. José Lenin makes and sells coffins, and began the business when he needed a job to help him get ahead with all his children. For this reason he decided to learn this trade in a workshop on his own. Later on, he decided to start his own business to help pay for his family’s expenses. He says that it was difficult to learn this profession but it has turned into a way for him to be able to get ahead. He is taking out this loan to have working capital to buy different products from which to build the coffins, such as wood, glue, nails, sandpaper, and formica laminated material which he needs for the final touches on his products. Sometimes he has to travel to buy these materials, and he thanks the Foundation’s helping hand and other organizations at these times when the country is passing through a difficult period, as it is currently.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wood, glue, nails, sandpaper, and formica laminated material

loans.name: Justacio Ramiro

texts.es:
El señor Justacio Ramiro P. tiene la edad de 66 años, su estado civil es casado, este Señor tiene 6 hijos Mario de 40 años que trabaja por cuenta propia, José tiene la edad de 38 años de edad que trabaja con el de forma individual, Luis Ramiro de 31 años labora como docente, Marlon tiene la edad de 25 años y labora reparando y armando bicicletas y su hija mujer mercedes tiene la edad de25 años que esta en 5 año de su carrera, su compañera de vida  trabaja en la administración  de una  venta de refrescos y gaseosa en su vivienda, en sus propósitos esta el darle mejoras a su vivienda y obtener mejores condiciones de vida y en sus deseos es que Dios le proporcione mas vida para seguir trabajando y así el pueda ganarse el pan de cada día.


El tiempo que ha tenido de tener su negocio es de 30años, su actividad económica es la de zapatería, el inicia este negocio por que a la edad de 12 años empezó a trabajar en talleres pero al pasar el tiempo los talleres tuvieron perdidas muy fuertes y fueron cerrados fue entonces que el decide instalar un negocio ubicado en las afueras del Mercado Santos Barcenas por lo que en este lugar es donde hay mas afluencia de clientes, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que necesita  realizar las compras de hilo encerado, pega y suela debido a que la compra de este se hace en Managua por lo que al por mayor le resulta mas conveniente y así con todos los materias que necesita podrá realizar los encargos que tiene pendiente.
texts.en:
Mr. Justacio Ramiro P. is sixty-six years old, married, and has six children: Mario is forty and is self-employed; José is thirty-eight and works independently; Luis Ramiro is thirty-one and a teacher; Marlon is twenty-five and works repairing and assembling bicycles; and his daughter Mercedes is twenty-five and in the fifth year of her career. His wife works in soft drink and soda sale administration in his house. His goal is to improve his housing and living conditions, and one of his wishes is that God supply him with more life so that he can continue working and providing bread for his family. He has had his business for thirty years. It is a shoe store. He started worked in workshops when he was twelve. As time went on the workshops began to have great losses and closed. It was then that he decided to start his own business outside of the Santos Barcenas market, since there is more traffic there. The loan is for resources for work -- he needs to be able to purchase waxed thread, glue, and proper shoe soles, which are bought in Managua because wholesale is more convenient for him. With all these materials that he needs he will be able to fulfill the orders he has pending.

Translated from Spanish by HannahLily P, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Candida Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Candida Rosa Martínez P. tiene la edad de 40 años, su estado civil es soltera, ella tiene 2 hijos de los cuales tiene 1 varón de la edad de 18 años que cursa recientemente el 5 año de secundaria y una mujer de 21 años de edad que estudia bionalisis clínico, sus propósitos son seguir adelante en su negocio por lo que este le genera los ingresos necesarios para mantener a su familia, en sus deseos esta el realizarle mejoras a su vivienda y también a la de su mama para que cuando se aproxime la temporada de invierno no pase dificultades en su vivienda por lo que agradece mantener la mano amiga de fundación león 2000 y otras organizaciones.


Su actividad económica es la venta de tortillas, que su negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitación en león, el tiempo que tiene de poseer el negocio es de 35 años, sus inicios comienzan desde la edad de 13 años que empieza vendiendo las tortillas por su barrio y mas tarde el negocio que era de una tía de Doña Rosa pasa a las manos de su mama Doña Paula pero debido a la edad de su mama decide dejarle el negocio a Doña Candida Rosa el financiamiento es para la compra de 10 quintales de maíz ya que la compra de este producto lo realiza de forma semanal y así obtiene mas ingresos y así podrá seguir manteniendo este negocio por lo que ha existido en toda su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Candida Rosa Martínez P. is 40 years old, single, and has 2 children, a 18 year-old son in 5th grade, secondary and a 21 year-old daughter who studies clinical bioanalysis. It is her goal to get ahead with her business as it generates the necessary income for her family and it is her wish to improve her dwelling as well as the one of her mother in order not to have difficulties during the winter season and therefore she is thankful for the helping hand from "Fundación León 2000" and other organizations.

She sells tortillas, her business is located at her house in León and she has been doing this for the last 35 years. She started selling tortillas in her neighborhood at the age of 13. Doña Rosa, the owner of the business, passed it on to her mother, Doña Paula, but due to her age she decided to pass on the business to Doña Candida Rosa. The loan will be spent on the purchase of 10 "quintales" (quintal = 100 lbs.) of corn, as this product is bought on a weekly basis which allows higher income and this way she can maintain the family business.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gloria Fransisca

texts.es:
La señora Gloria Francisca R. M. tiene la edad de 57 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Gloria tiene 2 hijas a su cargo su hija mayor tiene la edad de 38 años y acaba de recibirse como ingeniera en sistemas y no labora recientemente su otra hija tiene la edad de 39 años ella no labora y es secretaria bilingüe, su compañero de vida no labora, los propósitos  que tiene es de ayudar a sus hijas para que puedan administrar un negocio y así independizarse de ella y cada una trabaje por cuenta propia para que en futuro no tengan la necesidad de seguir con su mama. 




La ubicación de su negocio es en león, la dirección es la siguiente auto lote de occidente 1.c al sur 1c abajo Rpto aracely Pérez, su actividad económica es una pulpería donde vende lo siguiente: golosinas, cuadernos, lapiceros y jugos, el tiempo que tiene de tener este negocio es de 8 años, ella inicia este negocio por cuenta propia y al encontrarse en la necesidad de obtener un trabajo y empezó con un estante grande y al paso del tiempo fue incrementándose y así obtuvo lo que es su pulpería hoy, el motivo de su financiamiento es para la compra de juguetes y ropa debido a que se aproximan las temporadas festivas  así ofrecerá a sus clientes los diversos productos que exhibirá en su venta para que este le siga generando ingresos para su familia y ella misma.
texts.en:
Gloria, 57, is married and has 2 daughters. The oldest just qualified as a systems engineer but hasn't worked recently. Her other daughter is a bilingual secretary but isn't working. Her partner doesn't work. Her goal is to help her daughters set up a business and become independent so that they no longer have to depend on their mother. Her business is located in Leon. It's a small grocery where she sells: snacks, notebooks, pens and cold drinks. She's had the business for 8 years. She started the business because she needed work. She's built it from little more than a large stall, growing it over time into the store that it is today. The purpose of the loan is to buy toys and clothes for the upcoming holiday season. The money will allow her to offer her customers various products so that she can continue to earn an income for both her family and herself.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Hyde Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Hyde del Carmen M. O. tiene la edad de 26 años, su estado civil es acompañada, con 3 hijos a su cargo: el mayor con edad de9 años cursa el 2 grado de  primaria, el segundo con 4 años de edad no estudia y el mas pequeño con 7 meses de edad, su compañero de vida labora como ayudante de albañilería, los sueños de Hyde es tener su propia casa y en ella establecer su negocio  para  seguir generando ingresos para su familia y también para darle a sus clientes las comodidades necesarias, así podrá darle a sus hijos un buen futuro y obtendrán buena educación por medio de su esfuerzo.




La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta de mercadería en general como lo es: ropa para niños, camisas sport, calcetines y ropa interior, el  tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 5 años, ella inicia este negocio por la necesidad de independizarse de su familia y empezó la distribución de sus diferentes productos de forma ambulante y fue así como ella decidió incrementar mas en su negocio para que este le fuera una fuente de trabajo para el, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para invertir mas en sus productos así ofrecer calidad y cantidad a sus clientes para obtener mas ganancias y realizar los planes que tiene para su futuro.
texts.en:
Hyde del Carmen M. O. is 26 years old, lives with her partner and has 3 children. The oldest is 9 and in second grade, the second one is 4 years old and not yet in school, and the youngest is 7 months old. Her partner works as a bricklayer assistant. Hyde dreams of having her own home and setting up her business there so she can continue earning income for her family as well as to offer more conveniences to her customers. In this way and with her efforts, she will be able to give her children a good future and a good education. She sells merchandise such as clothing for children, sport shirts, socks and underwear and has had this business for the past 5 years. She started the business because she needed to become independent of her family. She began distributing her goods by means of traveling sales and then decided to increase her business so that it could become a source of income for her. The loan is for working capital to invest in more goods and to offer better quality and quantity to her customers and thus, have more earnings and work toward her future plans.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Maria Del Pilar

texts.es:
La señora Maria del Pilar Sánchez de 58 años, su estado civil es casada, tiene 5 hijos los cuales 3 dependen de ella, una hija mujer de 37 años no trabaja, Juan Manuel de 39 años es discapacitado su hijo menor de 4 años cursa el segundo nivel su esposo no labora actualmente, En sus propósitos esta mantener su negocio, que sus hijas y familia tengan una casa propia, además uno de los negocio que mas le gustan es la venta de fríjol por lo que le gustaría seguir adelante con este negocio ya que la situación del país no esta muy estable en sus propósitos tiene el de salir adelante con su familia por lo que todos sus hijos la apoyan es lo que es su negocio.


Ella inicia este negocio que es una pulpería, lo cual tiene 30 años de obtener este establecimiento en la que la expende los productos como: granos básicos  en lo que de alguna manera ella busca el pan de cada día y con su esposo e hijos decide la implantación de este negocio para tratar de salir adelante y es así como decide quedarse con la venta por que además de este negocio posee otros dos como lo es: la venta de nacatamales y un molino para moler maíz, por lo que recurre a este financiamiento para lograr sacar adelante su pulpería ya que tiene que realizar las compras en las diferentes distribuidoras y necesita buscar el lugar mas rentable donde ella pueda obtener los productos que expenderá.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Del Pilar S. is fifty-eight years old, married, and has five children. Three of her children are still dependent on her. Her thirty-seven-year-old daughter does not work. Thirty-nine-year-old Juan Manuel is handicapped. Her youngest is four and in his second year of school. Her husband does not work now. Some of the things she intends to do are keep up her business, get her daughters and family their own house, and, because she likes selling beans, succeed with that business so that she can do well in her country's unstable economy. She would still like to go on with this business, as the country's situation is not very stable. She hopes that she and her family can get ahead because all of her children support her in her business. Mrs. Maria Del Pilar's business is a local store. Thirty years ago she obtained this establishment in which she sells products like basic grains, and somehow puts bread on the table. With her husband and children she decided to establish this business to help them to leave in the future. This is why she decides to stay with the business. Plus, two similar business sale items are nacatameles and a mill to grind corn. She turns to this loan to succeed in getting her local store off the ground – she still has to make purchases from different distributors, and she needs to look for the most profitable place to get the products she will sell.

Translated from Spanish by HannahLily P, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Modesto Noel

texts.es:
Su nombre es Modesto Noel R. tiene la edad de 60 años, su estado civil es casado, este señor tiene 6 hijos pero no están a su cargo ya todos trabajan por cuenta propia, su esposa no labora es ama de casa, sus  propósito son de mantener activo su negocio por lo difícil que se torna la situación en este país y con este negocio el podría ahorrar para poder mantenerse en un futuro, en sus deseos esta el obtener mejoras para su vivienda y proporcionarle a sus nietos la ayuda necesaria mientras el pueda seguir trabajando.



La actividad económica a la que Don Noel se dedica es a la sastrería el tiempo que tiene de tener este negocio es de 38 años, el inicia este negocio desde la edad de 12 años y por su propia cuenta decide ingresar a un taller donde adquiere el conocimiento de este oficio lo cual el lo transforma en un trabajo el negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitación en león, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que el necesita realizar las compras de 150 yardas de tela de dril que se utiliza para la realización de los pantalones, compra de zziper, hilo y agujas para la maquina por lo que agradece a fundación León 2000 y otras organizaciones por mantener abierto su crédito.
texts.en:
Modesto Noel R. is 60 years old, and is married. He has 6 children but they don't live at home anymore and work to maintain themselves. His wife doesn't work, she is a housewife. Their purpose is to maintain active their business because of the difficulty of the changing situation in their country. With this business he can save to be able to maintain his family in the future. One of his wishes is to make improvements to his house, and to give his grandchildren the help necessary while he is able to continue working. The economic activity that Don Noel undertakes is a tailor shop. He has had this business for 38 years. He began the business at 12 years old, and for himself decided to enter a workshop where he would acquire the knowledge of this trade, which he would transform into a job. The business is located in his house in León. The finance is for capital for his work so he can buy 150 yards of material that he will use to make trousers, buy zippers, thread and needles for his machine. For this he gives thanks to Fundación León 2000 and other organisations for keeping open his credit.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.es:
L a señora Saturnina  pertenece al Banco Comunal “Chojchoni” del Distrito de Copani, Provincia de Yunguyo-Puno. Ella tiene 48 años, es madre de 8 hijos 4 mayores de edad y 4 que estudian a su lado, es casada, su esposo se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles compro  4 sacos de chuño. Tiene mucho tiempo trabajando con los banquitos.

Hoy se dedica a la  venta de cereales que trae de Bolivia y vende por mayor en Desaguadero.

Con el préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles que pagara en 4 cuotas comprara 2 sacos de cereales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Saturnina belongs to "Banco Comunal Chojchoni" of the District of Copani, Province of Yunguyo-Puno. She is 48 years old, a mother of 8 children, 4 legally of age and 4 who study and live with her. She is married and her husband buys and sells cattle for a living. With her first loan of S/.300.00 nuevos soles, she bought 4 sacks of potato flour. She has been working for a long time with the small banks.

Today she sells cereals which she brings from Bolivia and sells in bulk at Desaguadero. With the loan of S/.500.00 nuevos soles, to be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy 2 sacks of cereals.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cereals in bulk.

loans.name: Segundina Paulina

texts.es:
