La señora Paulina pertenece al Banco Comunal “Inmaculada Concepción” del Distrito de Juli, Provincia de Chucuito – Puno, vive en el Jr. Daniel Espezua Velasco Nº 146, Tiene 42 años y es madre de 2 hijos que están a su cargo, es casada y se dedica a la venta de golosinas. Segundina con el primer préstamo de  S/. 300.00 nuevos soles compro golosinas, galletas, gaseosas, etc. para aumentar su mercadería.

Al mismo tiempo teje chompas para los clientes que le hacen pedidos, ella compra golosinas de Desaguadero.

Con el préstamo que recibirá de S/.  1000.00 nuevos soles  el cual será pagado en 4 meses comprara mas golosinas, galletas, gaseosas, etc.

Su mayor deseo es poner una Tienda grande para poder vender por mayor.
texts.en:
Mrs Paulina belongs to "Banco Comunal Inmaculada Concepción" of the District of Juli, Province of Chucuito-Puno. She lives in Jr. Daniel Espezua Velasco No. 146. She is 42 years old and a mother of 2 children who depend on her. She is married and sells candy for a living. With the first loan of S/.300.00 nuevos soles Segundina bought candy, cookies, soft drinks etc. in order to increase her merchandise.

At the same time she knits sweaters ordered by her clients. She buys candy at Desaguadero.

With the loan of S/.1000.00 nuevos soles, to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy candy, cookies, soft drinks, etc. It is her greatest wish to have a big store so she can sell in bulk.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase candy and soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: María De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
La señora María P. es originaria de la bella ciudad de León donde actualmente se dedica a laborar en la venta de frutas y verduras.
Desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana ella abre sus puertas para iniciar con la comercialización de los perecederos y desde el momento que abre su establecimiento, es visitada por los clientes que demandan de las frutas y verduras.

Como todo negocio en desarrollo, el negocio de la señora P. requiere de inversión y para ello ha solicitado un crédito en CEPRODEL para la compra de los perecederos y de esta manera continuar con el negocio que es su único sustento.
texts.en:
María P. is originally from the beautiful city of León where she works selling fruit and vegetables. During the early hours of the morning she opens her doors to start marketing her perishables and from the moment that she opens her establishment, she is visited by clients that demand the fruit and vegetables. Like all developing businesses, Mrs P.'s business requires investment and for this she is requesting a credit with CEPRODEL to buy perishables and in this way continue with her business, which is her only support.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de las frutas y verduras

payments.comment: correction due to overpayment for business 75593

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase 1 piece of cattle

loans.name: Viviana

texts.es:
La señora Viviana es socia del Banco Comunal “Espíritu Santo” del centro poblado de Chimbo del distrito y Provincia de Yunguyo-Puno. Tiene 36 años de edad y es madre de 4 hijos que estudian, es casada. Ella trabaja sola en la crianza de animales menores (ovejas, chanchos, etc) Con el primer préstamo de S/.  300 .00 nuevos soles compro chanchitos para engorde y al que sigue dedicándose.

 Ahora desea iniciar un nuevo negocio, y con el préstamo que obtendrá de S/. 800.00 nuevos soles  comprara Golosinas y galletas para vender por mayor en la ciudad de Tacna.
 Su meta es que sus negocios salgan bien para obtener más ganancias.
texts.en:
Señora Viviana is a member of the communal bank "Espíritu Santo" (Holy Spirit) in the town of Chimbo in the district and province of Yunguyo-Puno. She is 36 and is the mother of 4 children, who are in school. She is married. She works raising smaller animals (sheep, pigs, etc.). With her first loan of 300 nuevos soles, she purchased young pigs to fatten. She continues doing this work. Now she would like to start a new business, and with this loan of 800 nuevos soles, she will purchase candy and cookies to sell wholesale in the city of Tacna. Her goal is that her businesses do well so she can make more profits.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase candy and cookies wholesale

loans.name: William Genaro

texts.es:
El señor William Genaro C. es originario del municipio de Telica de la ciudad de León y se dedica a su actividad de pintado profesional realizando esta actividad ambulantemente donde le soliciten el servicio. El señor William es experto en pintar casas, muebles entre otros y este ha sido sus único sustento desde muy joven.

Hoy en dia a la edad de 45 años continua destacándose como un buen pintor en su municipio y para llevar a cabo esta actividad hace uso de los créditos brindados por Ceprodel el cual los ha invertido directamente en la compra de las pinturas. Una vez más espera que su crédito sea otorgado y de esta forma continuar con el mantenimiento de su familia a la que tanto ama.
texts.en:
William Genaro C. comes from the municipality of Telica in the city of León and works as a professional travelling painter, working where people request his service. William is an expert at painting houses and furniture among others, and this has been his only support since he was very young. Today at 45 years old he continues to stand out as a good painter in his municipality, and to continue to do this activity he makes use of the loans granted by Ceprodel, of which he has invested directly in buying paints. Once more he hopes that a loan will be bestowed and in this way he can continue to maintain his familiy that he loves so much.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Paint

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
La señora Antonia es socia del Banco Comunal “Espíritu Santo” del Centro Poblado D. Chimbo, Distrito y Provincia D. Yunguyo-Puno. Tiene 69 años D. edad, es casada y madre D. 6 hijos, su esposo trabaja en la compra y venta D. animales  D. carga  “burros”, ella no estudio por que nunca conoció a sus padres y fue criada por sus familiares, por lo cual tuvo que trabajar desD. pequeña para mantenerse.

Con el primer préstamo recibido D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que obtuvo compro “burros” para que su esposo pueda iniciar este negocio, actualmente sigue con esto y también cría ganado vacuno para engorD..

Con este préstamo que recibirá D. S/. 2000.00 nuevos soles comprara 01 vaca  D. la Feria D. Chacachaca, crédito que pagara en 05 cuotas.
texts.en:
Ms Antonia is a member of the community bank "Espíritu Santo” of Centro Poblado in Chimbo, in the district and province of Yunguyo-Puno. She is 69 years old, married, and the mother of 6. Her husband works buying and selling pack animals (donkeys). She never went to school because she never knew her parents: she was brought up by relatives and therefore had to work from a very young age to support herself. With her first loan of S/. 300.00 nuevos soles ($100 USD), she bought donkeys so that her husband could start the business, which they are still active in as well as raising cattle for fattening up. With this loan request of S/. 2000.00 nuevos soles ($650 USD), Antonia will buy a cow at the Chacachaca Fair. She will repay the loan in 5 installments.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy livestock (1 cow)

loans.name: Ángela Lorena

texts.es:
La señora Ángela Lorena es una dama que se dedica a laborar arduamente en el municipio de Telica en León para llevar a cabo su sueño de brindarle un techo digno a su pequeño hijo en edad escolar. Ha iniciado a reconstruir su casa de habitación y lo ha llevado a cabo poco a poco hasta acabar con esta obra que ha iniciado. 

Ceprodel ha sido un apoyo fundamental en su construcción por la razón de que le ha apoyado con créditos que los ha utilizado para la compra de los materiales de construcción. Hoy en día una vez más ha acudido a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito que le permita la compra de bloque, cemento, arena, zinc y hierro para continuar con esta construcción y así brindarle las condiciones necesarias a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Ms Ángela Lorena is a woman who works arduously in the municipality of Telica in León so that she can make her dream of giving her young school-aged son a worthy home come true. She has begun rebuilding her home and is making improvements slowly but surely to finish this project. Ceprodel has been of great support in the renovation as she has been able to use previous loans to buy construction materials. Now,once again, she is asking Ceprodel for a loan to buy cement blocks, cement, sand, zinc and iron to continue with the construction and thus improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials for home improvement

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
La señora Ana Maria pertenece al Banco Comunal “Espíritu Santo” del Centro Poblado de Chimbo, Distrito y Provincia de Yunguyo-Puno. Tiene 53 años  y es madre de un hijo mayor que tiene familia, es casada y junto a su esposo se dedican al negocio de crianza de animales para engorde, ella inicio con este negocio cuando tenia 22 años de edad y al mismo tiempo puso su pequeña tienda de abarrotes. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles inicio su negocio y compro chanchos y ovejas al que actualmente se dedica.

Con el préstamo  que recibirá de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles el cual será pagado en 4 cuotas comprara 01 par de ovejas de raza.

Su deseo es continuar con la crianza de animales y mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ana Maria is a member of the Communal Bank 'Espíritu Santo' of the Centro Poblado de Chimbo, district and province of Yunguyo-Puno. She is 53 years old and is a mother of one grown up son who has a family of his own. She is married and together with her husband, they own a business where they raise and fatten livestock. She started this business when she was 22 years old; at the same time she established a store where she sold groceries. With her first loan of 300 Soles, she started her business and bought pigs and sheep- this is her livelihood today. With the loan she will receive of 500 Soles, which will be paid in 4 installments, she will purchase a pair of pedigree sheep. Her dream is to continue raising livestock and to better her income.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sheep

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs S. lives in Hung Yen commune, Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province. She is 45 years old and has five children, two in school. She is a member of TYM since 2002. Her main income comes from raising pigs. Her husband is a physician and her son is a worker, so her family’s income is stable. But she would like to have more income to secure her children's future, so she is requesting a loan to expand her pig-raising business.

loans.use: To buy more pigs and and pig food

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs Nguyen Thi H. 31 years old. She is married  and has two children. She lives in Hung Trung commune, Hung Nguyen district , Nghe An province. She has been in TYM Fund since 2002. Her main income comes from raising chicken on a farm and growing rice. As her previous loans have been used wisely, her income is becoming more stable with more invest in her children’s education. Now she is requesting a loan to buy more chickens and chicken feed to further grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and chicken feed

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs Nguyen Thi T. 44 years old. She has three children, two of whom are grown. She lives with her husband and her children in HungYen commune, Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province. She joined in TYM Fund six years ago. To ear money, she raises ducks and her husband sells pork.  Since joining TYM, her family's income has improved. She hopes to continue raising their standard of living, so she is requesting a loan to buy more ducks and to purchase rice for farming.

loans.use: To buy ducks and rice

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi T. is 43 years old.  She has been part of TYM Fund since 2002.  She lives in Hung Yen commune, Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province with her husband and four children.  Her husband is a construction worker.  Now her family’s main income is from raising chickens and her husband’s salary.  Their business developed well and brings her family an income of 2.5 million VND (about $140 US) per month.  This time she wants to borrow 11 million VND ($650 US) to buy more chickens and chicken feed for raising them.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Hoang Thi N. is 43 years old.  She joined TYM in 2002.  She has five children, three of whom are grown up. Now her family’s main income comes from raising chickens, a grocery shop, and her son's salary.  With sales of 12 million VND ($720 US) per month, her family’s economy is developing.  In the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 20 million VND ($1,175 US) to invest in her grocery shop and buy more chickens for raising.

loans.use: To invest in her grocery shop and buy more chickens for raising.

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarin O., 52, is a local farmer who has been growing rice and vegetables for income for about 20 years. She is married and has no children. Her husband, Mr. Mean Meas, is 64 years old and is a local carpenter who makes tables, chairs and beds for sale. They live in Loloksar Commune, Pursat Province.

Sarin needs to have two oxen to use to help her work by plowing the field; hence, she is deciding to seek a loan of $350 to make that possible.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mr. Thy S. is 26 years old and a rice farmer, who also raises female ducks to make eggs to sell wholesale to customers. His wife, Mrs. Sokthavy Noun, 20, is also a farmer and has two young children who live at home. They live in Svayloung Commune in Pursat Province.

Thy applied for a loan of 1,500,000 riel ($375) to purchase more ducks for breeding and hopes that a loan will help him to increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase more ducks

loans.name: Mrs. Cheng Sith Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eighteen people who live in the Por Pel Pok village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia, selected Mrs. Cheng S. as the village bank president. She has a plot of land on which she cultivates rice to sell. She does not have enough rice seeds to plant a new crop, S. she is requesting a loan to buy more rice seeds. Her husband, Mr. Nheom Pheach, helps her in the field. Mrs. Cheng S. is 33 years old and has five children; one is employed in a garment factory, three others attend the local school, and the youngest child is four years old.

loans.use: Buy more rice seeds to cultivate rice to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Chan Thy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank includes twenty people, who live in the Por Pel Pok village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambridge. Mrs. Chan Thy S. is the village bank president, and she is rice farmer. She does not have enough rice seeds to plant a new crop. S. she requests a loan to buy more rice seeds. With some of the money from the loan, she alS. plant to buy fishing nets for Mr. Nu Saron, her husband, who is a fisherman in the local village.

Mrs. Chan Thy S. is 52 years old and the mother of five children; two children are employed in a garment factory, and the others attend the local school. (Mr. Met S.'s wife is requesting a loan alS., and she is in the picture.)

loans.use: Buy more rice seeds for planting

loans.name: Sovann

texts.en:
Mrs. Sovann S. is 28 years old and married. Her business is in making cement jars to sell for income to sustain her family. She can make 3 jars a day, earning approximately $3 per day. She now lives with her old mother and seven siblings, all who are farmers who grow rice and vegetables. They all live in Thnoatchrum Commune in Pursat Province.

Sovann is applying for $1,000 to buy more raw materials to use for making jars and hopes the loan will help her to increase her revenue.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials

loans.name: Thy's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Thy C. is the leader of a group of four members, who all live in the Por Pel Pok village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She and her husband are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot where they cultivate rice to sell. They have four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, and two help their parents with their business. Although Mrs. Thy C.’s family are employed in different businesses, they still cannot afford lumber to build their house. Thus, Mrs. Thy C. requests a loan to buy lumber. (Mrs. Lakhena Y.'s husband, who is requesting a loan, is also pictured here.)

loans.use: Buy lumber to build the house

loans.name: Roatha's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Raotha T. is a group leader of six members, who all live in the Angk Tnaot Kaeut village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She owns 0.5 hectare farm, where she cultivates rice to sell. Her husband, Mr. Hang Sarun is a construction worker who earns a small amount of money for supporting the family. Although they have different businesses, they still cannot earn enough to support the family well. So Mrs. Raotha T. requests a loan to buy piglets to start a new pig-breeding business, which she hopes will increase her income. Mrs. Raotha T. is 37 years old and the mother of four children; three are enrolled in the local school, and the youngest one is 2 years old.

loans.use: Buy piglets to start a new breeding business

loans.name: Thany

texts.en: Mrs. Thany L. is 39 years old and a local farmer, who makes a living growing rice crops, which is a common business for Cambodia’s people. She is a widow with two children, both in secondary school. Thany hopes to have a cow to help her to plow the farmland, but she is lacking money to make that possible; hence, she decided to apply for a loan of 1,500,000 riel ($375) to purchase a cow. Thany lives in the area of Svayloung Commune in Pursat Province.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Mrs. Sareth Koem Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eleven people who live in the Angk Tnaot Kaeut village in TaK. Province, Cambodia, are members of the village bank loan group. Mrs. Sareth K. ws selected by the members as the village bank president. She owns 0.5 hectare, where she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. U. Tuy, is a construction worker, who earns a small amount to support the family. Although Mrs. Sareth K. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot earn enough to support the family well. So Mrs. Sareth K. is requesting a loan to buy piglets to start a breeding business and she hopes to increase her income after she sells her pigs. She is 41 years old and the mother of three children who attend the local school.

loans.use: Buy piglets to start pig-breeding business

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Khen Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sok K. was selected as the village bank president by the 21 members of the group. They live in the Veal Kandal village in Kandal Province, Cambodia.  She has a 1-hectare farm where she cultivates rice to sell. Her field in infertile, and the crops have been badly affected. To resolve this problem, Mrs. Sok K. requests a loan to buy fertilizers to improve the field and make her rice crop more productive. She is a 62-year-old widow with five children; two are employed in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, and the other two children attend the local school.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer to increase the productivity of the rice field

loans.name: Mrs. Touch Ros Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people who live in Pou Preah Sang Village in Takeo Province, Cambodia, make up the village bank loan group; all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Touch R. is the village bank president and she is a farmer. She owns a 1-hectare plot where she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Van Pov, is a motorbike taxi driver. He earns a small amount to support his family.

Although Mrs. Touch R. and her husband have different businesses, they still live in poor conditions and they cannot support the household well. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Touch R. requests a loan to buy piglets to start a breeding business. She hopes she can increase her income with this new business.

loans.use: Buy piglets to start breeding business

loans.name: Yoeung

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeung L., 28, is a widow and a farmer who grows rice and vegetables, such as water-lily and cabbages. She started in this job in 1999 and has had much experience. She works hard and is also a good mother who can provide her two young children with food and with education. Yoeung lives in Svayloung Commune in Pursat Province.

Yoeung is requesting a loan of 200,000 riel ($50) to buy chickens to raise, and is hopeful that a loan will help her to increase her income.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthy C. was born in 1962 and she now lives in the Svay village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Touch Kheang, is a driver (pictured here). They have four children, two of whom are employed in garment factory, and two repair cars. Because their work place is far from the house, they usually have to pay a great deal of money for transportation. Thus, Mrs. Chanthy C. requests a loan to add to her savings so she can buy a motorbike for her children to go to work.

loans.use: Add to savings to buy a motorbike for transportation to work

loans.name: Nat

texts.en:
Mr. Nat N. is a farmer in the Choeung Prey village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. He owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He is 42 years old and the father of six children; one is employed in the garment factory, and the other five children are enrolled in the local school.

Mr. Nat N.'s wife, Mrs. Pom Eang, breeds ducks to earn a living. This business is going well, and she wants to expand it. So Mr. Nat N. requests a loan to buy duck food for his wife’s breeding business.

loans.use: Buy duck food for breeding business

loans.name: Channa

texts.en: Mr. Channa R. lives in the Tep Phyrom village in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. He installs windows. This business is going well, and he wants to expand it. So Mr. Channa R. requests a loan to buy more equipment for doing construction work. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's living conditions. His wife, Mrs. Roeun Sreyna, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Mr. Channa R. is 24 years old and has a 3-year-old child.

loans.use: Buy more equipment for construction work

loans.name: Varn

texts.en:
Mr. Varn S. lives in the Chum Tup Morn village in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. He is 49 years old and the father of four children; one is employed in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, and two other attend the local school. His wife, Mrs. Kun Mean, is a farmer.

Mr. Varn S. makes beds to earn a living. His business is going well, and he wants to expand it. So he requests a loan to buy more equipment for his bed-making business. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: Buy more equipment to make more beds

loans.name: Sony

texts.en:
Mr. Sony N. is 29 years old and he now lives in the Tep Phyrom village in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. He has two children who are too young to work or study. He repairs motorcycles. His wife, Mrs. Choeun Phat, is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living.

Their family has less very little income to support their household. Thus, Mr. Sony N. requests a loan to add to his savings to build a house to improve living conditions for his family.

loans.use: Add to his savings to build a house for the family to improve living conditions

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mom S., 59, is married and has 8 children. She is a housewife, cooking for her family members and taking care of the household. Mom S. and her family live in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. Her husband, Tep Van, is 78 years old and earns income growing rice crops and selling them at a market. On average, Tep Van makes US$4 per day. The family is financially supported also by two of the children who work as construction workers and make around US$3 per day each. At present, Mom S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike for her children to be able to have an easier commute to work. The remainder of the loan will be used to purchase fertilizers for her husband's rice farming business.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorbike and fertilizers for rice farming

loans.name: Thea

texts.en: Mrs. Thea M. lives in the Tep Phyrom village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living.  She is 29 years old and the mother of four children; three children attend the local school, and the other child is 4 years old. Her husband, Mr. Mom Vanna, is a motorbike driver. Even though they have different businesses, they do not have much money to support their household. So, Mrs. Thea M. requests a loan to buy some piglets for breeding and start a new business.

loans.use: Buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Lut

texts.en: Lut L., 33, is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. Lut L. is a housewife, cooking food and looking after her children. She also owns a small business, raising pigs and growing rice. On average, Lut L. makes about US$4 per day, the same as her husband (pictured in the photo) who is a construction worker and earns income building houses. Currently, Lut L. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to be able to purchase livestock and fertilizers for her farmland and raise more pigs. She believes that the loan will help improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase of additional pigs and fertilizers

loans.name: Thy

texts.en: Mr. Thy N. is a farmer who lives in the village of Samboo in the Kampong Speu Province. He owns a piece of land on which he cultivates rice and earns his living. His wife, Mrs. Phorn Nak, is a pig breeder. Even though they have different businesses, they do not have enough money to support their family and improve living conditions. Thus, Mr. Thy N. decided to request a loan to add to his savings. He would use the capital to build a house for family to live in better conditions. He is 34 years old and the father of three children who are too young to work or study. His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To build a house for family to live in better conditions.

loans.name: Vun

texts.en:
Vun Y., 26, is married and has two young children. Vun Y. and her family live in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. She also  takes care of her old mother who stays at home. Vun Y. earns income selling fish at a market, making about US$2.5 of profit per day. Her husband (pictured in the photo) is a fisherman, providing fish for Vun Y. to sell, as well as selling some of the catch to other fish sellers, thus earning about US$4 per day. In a typical month, the family spends US$ 66 on food and US$21 on utilities.
Vun Y. is currently asking for a loan of US$400 from Kiva via Credit MFI, a local partner, to be able to purchase a wooden boat for her husband's fishing business. She believes that the loan will help improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase of a wooden boat

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair her house to live in better conditions.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen H., 26, is married, has a child, and lives in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. She is a housewife, taking care of the household and looking after her child. In addition, Pen H. grows rice crops, but only enough for the family's own needs. Pen H.'s husband (on the right side of the photo) earns income working as a construction worker and blacksmith. On average, he makes around US$4 per day. He has been engaged in the profession since 2000, having learned it from his father. 
In a typical month, Pen H.'s family spends US$45 on food. To help generate more money to support the family, Pen H. is now applying for a loan of US$400 to be able to purchase a cow that would be used for plowing the farmland as well as for transporting the rice crops during the harvest season. Previously, Pen H. had to hire a hand tractor to plow the land. She believes that the loan will allow her to save money and earn more profit.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Ziyaddin

texts.en: Ziyaddin was born in 1975 and lives in the town of Khachmaz in Azerbaijan. Five years ago he established his own home-building company. He is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy new supplies and equipment to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy supplies and equipment for a home-building business

loans.name: Sakhiba

texts.en: Sakhiba (her husband is seen her because she was not available to be photographed) was born in 1981 and lives in the town of Khachmaz in Azerbaijan. Her husband makes a living repairing cars. He has been in this business for three years and is applying with his wife for a $1,200 loan to buy parts and equipment he needs to improve his small company.

loans.use: to buy parts and equipment for a car-repair business

loans.name: Reay

texts.en:
Reay P., 33, is married and has three children, two of whom are students, while the third is still too young to attend school. She lives in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. Reay P. and her husband earn income raising pigs and farming rice, having learned it from their parents. On average, the two of them together earn around US$6 per day. In a typical month, the family spends US$60 on food, US$5 on utilities, and US$1 on education. Reay P. wants to see her children educated so that they can find well-paid jobs and do not have to engage in farming. 
Reay P. currently needs a loan of US$600 to purchase fertilizers and feed for pigs. Some of the money will also be used for doing necessary repairs to the family's house.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers and feed for pigs

loans.name: Roeung

texts.en:
Roeung C., 30, is married and has three children. The family lives in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. Roeung earns income working as a tailor, typically making US$2.5 per day. Roeung has been involved in the tailoring business since 1998 after finishing a specialized school. Roeung's husband works in the fishery department, making about US$2 per day. Every month, the family spends US$50 on food, US$10 on utilities, US$5 on their children’s education, and US$10 on transportation.
At present, Roeung C. is asking for a loan of US$600 to be able to purchase a sewing machine to help in her business. In the future, she wants to open a small tailoring shop.

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine for a tailoring business

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Pham Thi Q. is 48 years old.  She has five children and all of them are grown up.  She has been in TYM since 2002.  During her long time in TYM, she has always repaid her loans on time.  Now her main income is from raising chickens, growing rice, and the salary of her son, an income of about 3.5 million VND ($200) per month.  This time she wants to borrow 10 million ($600) to buy more chickens and chicken feed for raising them.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long T., 36, is married and has 4 children, one of whom works, two are students, while the youngest one is still too young to attend school. She lives in the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Since 1996, she has been earning income making and selling different types of baskets - a skill that she learned from her parents. Long T.'s average earnings are US$2 per day, while her husband, working as a construction worker, makes US$5 per day. The couple is also supported by one of their children who works as cleaner. In a typical month, the family spends around US$45  on food, US$7 on utilities, US$15 on their children’s education, and US$10 on transportation.
Currently, Long T. would like to take out a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorbike

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Pham Thi H. is 31 years old.  She lives with her husband and her child in HungYen commune, Hung Nguyen distict, Nghe An province.  She has been in TYM Fund for 5 years.  Now her main income is from raising pigs, and her husband’s income is from selling pork.  This time she wants to borrow 13 million VND ($775 US) to buy more pigs and food for raising them.

loans.use: To buy more pigs and pig food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a restaurant.

loans.name: Dy

texts.en:
Dy C., 24, is married and lives with her husband and child in the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Since 2003, she has been growing rice crops and selling them, making about US$3 per day, while her husband, engaged in the firewood-sales business, earns approximately US$5 per day. 
Dy C. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase a cow. The cow will help Dy C. plow the farmland and will pull the cart that Dy C.'s husband uses to transport wood.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Le Thi H. is 32 years old.  She lives with her husband and two children in Hung Nguyen district.  Her husband is a worker.  In 2006, she joined TYM and borrowed a loan to invest in raising pigs and chickens and small trading. Now she owns a fertilizer shop.  This business is developing well and is her family’s main income.  For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 10 million VND ($600 US) to invest in fertilizer.

loans.use: To invest in fertilizer for her business.

loans.name: Ong

texts.en: Ong N. R., 21, is single and lives with her old mother and father in the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She runs a small business, washing cars and motorbikes, and can make about US$3 per day. Because the machine that helps increase the water pressure is broken, Ong N. R. currently needs a loan to fix it, since the car washing business is the family's main source of income.

loans.use: Repair of a water pressure machine

loans.name: Song

texts.en:
Song S., 34, is married and lives with her husband (pictured in the photo) and four children in the Siem Reap, Cambodia. Three of the children are students, while the fourth one is still too young to attend school. Song is a housewife, looking after her children and cooking food for the family. Besides doing the housework, she is also engaged in a pig raising business through which she can make a dollar per day, while her husband, working as a fisherman, earns US$4 per day. Song and her husband work very hard to support their children’s studies, giving each child US$0.25 to go to school. 
At present, Song S. would like to take out a loan of US$400 to purchase a wooden boat for her husband to help him catch more fish for sale.

loans.use: Purchase of a wooden boat
